title: The National WWII Museum, New Orleans
review_list:
You will love it whether you are a wwII buff or not! Great museum that is very easy to navigate and enjoy.

Always a new exhibit at the WWII Museum. This trip we focused on the Road to Japan. The exhibit was incredible and the chance to hear your selection of a solider, sailor or marine talk about the events you were seeing left everyone feeling the emotions along with the exhibit. Excellent displays. Friendly and knowledgeable staff and volunteers.
Don't miss...


More  



The growth of this museum has been tremendous. To date it is an amazing place to spend the day. It can bring on strong emotions. My children enjoy this place too, so many things on display. A special treat is when older folks who volunteer with the museum are there to tell their story and share their scrapbooks. Not to...


More  



Allow yourself plenty of time - my wife and I only arrived after lunch - which was not enough time to see the whole museum. And wear comfortable shoes. Excellent museum.

I really enjoyed the 4D movie, narrated by Tom Hanks, and the various tableaus throughout the museum depicting what the soldiers went through during this war. I think that this movie should travel throughout the US so that current generations will see what it took to gain the lifestyle that we enjoy today, to appreciate what those in the armed...


More  



Pay the extra 5 or 6 bucks to watch the movie, it was incredible! There is so much to see, give yourself at least 4 hours to see
It all!

The day was very cold and windy so we opted to visit the WW2 Museum which was formerly called the D-Day Museum. They have 4 buildings with different themes dealing with various aspects of the war. In one building are 2 different interactive large scale exhibits. One on Europe and one on Japan. Both take about an hour to go...


More  



the displays are awesome the details to authentic scenes were breath taking and the Movie was chilling to know we had all kinds of Americans who died for our world freedom from evil.

So much to see and do here, you could easily spend a day. We were here for 3 hours and still did not have time to see the movies (costs extra). Very high quality experience throughout with some fascinating exhibits. If you are a history buff, interested in the WWII era, or know someone who fought or was affected by...


More  



This place has a lot to offer and it is still growing! Fabulous displays of actual WWII Mustangs, B-17 bombers, tanks, and more. The movies are first rate. Lots to see, we spent a day and didn't see it all. The cafe was great, large portions!

title: Jackson Square, New Orleans
address: 615 Pere Antoine Alley, New Orleans, LA 70116
review_list:
Nice place. Artists and bands playing great place to sit and relax. The church was closed off. Would have loved to see inside

Spent some time here, was a great spot to take in the scenery and relax. A small piece of quiet away from the crowds.

This place isn't open in the evening (probably for good reason), but it is a nice walk during the day. It's right across the street from St. Louis Cathedral - another sight to see.

Located right in between the Mississippi River and St Louis Cathedral. This park has an excellent view of the Cathedral. It is a good place to grab some beignets from Cafe Du Monde which is near by and sit on a bench and relax. It has a beautiful water fountain and statue.

It was nice to see the various artists and street performers around. You do however need to keep an eye out for the homeless people, they are pretty vocal about asking for hand outs.

We visited during Mardis Gras and there was a lot of free entertainment taking place in the square as well as a lot of artists displaying their works. Unfortunately the Cathedral was closed so we did not get a chance to see inside. Maybe we will go to Mass on Ash Wednesday--if we do I will review it.

Beautiful stroll, artists, mystics, musicians, people of all kinds. Great views, good food around the corner. This is a terrific walk after breakfast or lunch.

This is a wonderful area to see! a lot of amazing architecture and buildings. Like a tribute to this beautiful city!

I loved seeing all the artists and street performers. You can feel the history. Even late at night it is safe to walk around. Cafe du Monde is right across the street. Best place to get a picture of the church is on top of the tour dealer across from the park. A must place to see if in New...


More  



If you are in New Orleans you simply must go to see Jackson Square. It is a beautiful historic park and church. Also, there are great local artists and musicians all around to enjoy.

title: St. Louis Cathedral, New Orleans
address: 615 Pere Antoine Alley, New Orleans, LA 70116
review_list:
You can't miss St. Louis Cathedral! It is in the heart of the city and is the symbol of New Orleans. The interior is even more beautiful than then outside. If you don't want to enter the main sanctuary because a Mass is going on, this year is the Year of Mercy Jubilee, and there is a Holy Door at...


More  



This is a must see while in New Orleans...this church is absolutely beautiful Also there is usually someone to give you the history & answer questions about this stunning catheral

This church is breathtaking and a great photo opportunity. It is located close to Cafe Du Monde to try a beingnet and other wonderful places to visit in the city! So awesome to see!

This centrally located church is very identifiable with New Orleans. It easily seen from many places due to its recognizable spires. It is across from the famous Jackson Sq. where we even saw a wedding taking place. My wife and I did go inside during Mass for a few minutes. We also started our ghost tour on the steps of...


More  



This church is beautiful if you have a chance should see. If you are interested in ghost sign up for a ghost tour which will explain the history of the church.

We attended Saturday evening mass here and it was a beautiful church with a lovely mass. It was well attended too.

Beautiful Cathedral inside and out. The Ceiling on the inside has an amazing painting on it. The outside is very picturesque. If you go to the back of the square the pictures get better and better. It almost looks like a fairy tale castle. Their are horse rides and the famous Cafe Du Monde near by. As well as the...


More  



The church is a must see regardless of religious beliefs. It's beautiful inside! Myself and my girlfriend attended a wedding reception here last year. It was great.

I loved the ceilings, the organ (huge pipe) the alter and the stained glass! The reverance and the mystique of an old church just makes me marvel!

Beautiful building and square. It was very close to the festivities on bourbon street and offered a nice quiet place to relax. There were many street vendors selling things from artwork to souvenirs.

title: Frenchmen Street, New Orleans
review_list:
Where its happening..here you will find many unique artist performing in many different music style's.

There are many great clubs featuring local musical talent. The area has a nice vibe and we actually liked it a lot more than Bourbon St. We especially liked the Andy J. Forest Trio at the 30/90 Club.

I walked down this street one early morning and it appeared very interesting--from the look of the businesses I would think the "night life" hear and Jazz would be prevelant. If I were here alone, I would venture down one evening for sure!!!

You can find lot of nice music venues and not so crazy like Bourbon Street.You can easily arrive from French Quarter by walk .

This area of the city is fantastic. There are alot of places where music is flowing and the locals are happy to share and delight you with stories and where to find great food! We are staying nearby for a trip in a month and could not be more excited to be near this location. If you love Jazz music...


More  



This is the place to go. This street is lined with jazz clubs of every description. There are a number of lovely local restaurants with excellent food. Browse the artists market if you can.

This is the place to go for live music, especially jazz. There is not much music left on Bourbon Street, but there is plenty here at the bars of Frenchmen Street.

Frenchmen Street was an unexpected surprise. My wife and I and 2 friends were staying on Royal St. just 2 blocks from Frenchmen. We walked over to it one night since we heard all the music and saw the lights. There are numerous bars, of course. Almost all have good music and good eats. My wife and I were turned...


More  



Jazz poured out of several venues and entertainment spilled onto the street! THE location for excellent music without drunks elbow to elbow.

This is a place where the locals hang out. If you are looking for pristine restaurants this is not the area to be in. The restaurant are good and the music is great. If you are looking for a good time this an area you should out.

title: Garden District, New Orleans
review_list:
We did a self guided walking tour. Loved the beautiful homes and charm. Finished a great Sunday afternoon in the district with a fabulous dinner at Commanders Palace, a must when you are in the Garden District!

Such a beautiful place to visit while in New Orleans and the home of cemetery No.1...there are lovely book stores, cafes and quirky shops. I loved this part of town and would recommend a walking tour - mine included a visit to one of the mansions in the area which was a treat! Seeing the homes of the rich and...


More  



Beautiful homes contained in this historic district. You can pay for a guided tour or buy a walking tour booklet at bookstore and go it alone. Be sure to stop at Commanders for lunch after. Be sure to have a reservation

The best way to tour the areas is to just hop on-hop off a street car & click your way through the antebellum houses. Some of those are really remarkable & worth a gaze. You can also visit the Lafayette cemetery in the area.

Fortunately for me I wandered through this lovely part of town taking photographs BEFORE Katrina. It was a real disaster and the damage was horrific,both from the flood waters and vandals.

We spent many hours just walking and driving around in the area. The houses and their landscaping are amazing. From large stately mansions to lovely but still charming smaller homes, it is just an eye opening look back into time. St Charles Street is the epicenter of the Garden District but do not pass up Magazine Street for shopping, drinks...


More  



While I was visiting my cousin in New Orleans, I took a walking tour of the Garden District. It was SO great. We had an entertaining gentleman to lead the tour and he took us all over the area. We toured the cemetery as well as the neighborhood with many beautiful homes. He pointed out Peyton Manning's family home as...


More  



saw some pretty cool peoples houses including Peyton manning also saw a house ahs(American horror story) was shot in

I so wish the cable car was running this day we visited but was able to see the railways covered with parade patrons. Not something I'd ever seen before so we took it in and had fun. The Garden District is so pretty with huge trees covering the streets. Not being from a large city we did ask about parking....


More  



There is so much more in Nola than French Quater (don´t get me wrong - you need to see those areas too!) and Garden District is one of them. Take a day to stroll around, you don´t regret it!

title: French Quarter, New Orleans
address: Canal St to Esplanade Ave, Mississippi River to N Rampart St, New Orleans, LA
review_list:
This place is interesting and worth seeing if you are in New Orleans. Don't miss the WW2 museum and make sure you check our Frenchman's street. I also recommend the battlefield.

New Orleans and its french Quarter is defiantly a place to visit once in a life time. Lovely houses, charming people and lot's of bars and restaurants... and jazz and step dance all around. Try to be there for Mardi Gras!

Have to say a little overwhelming. Lots of very drunk people. Not my cup of tea
It's okay to drink and have fun but there was too many way too drunk

We were in New Orleans only about a month before Mardi Gras and the excitement is building. The French Quarter is prettyi much the epicenter of it all. There are bars and music everywhere under normal circumstances. Now it's even more so. There's music on the streets and almost spontaneous parades and costumes happen. I cite the rather impromptu parade...


More  



Went midday with the family and walked the many old streets. Really feel like we were in another country. Hit Bourbon and Royale and all the famous streets. Not a place you want to take your young family after dark though. Bourbon turns into a party place.

Every one goes to Bourbon but much more to experience.Walk down Royal street and see the antique stores.Go to Cafe du Monde and have a Beignet

The place to be you get architecture, art, drinks, music, parades, and great food. I fell in love with the city!

This is what I know about the French Quarter;
It was founded as a military-style grid of seventy squares in 1718 by French Canadian naval officer Jean Baptiste Bienville, the French Quarter of New Orleans has charted a course of urbanism for parts of four centuries. Bienville served as governor for financier John Law’s Company of the Indies, which in...


More  



Close to all the cool pubs, restaurants and attractions. Walking distance to everywhere. We were here during Mardi Gras and oh boy party non stop at every street corner.

If you're looking to cut loose and have a good time I would definitely recommend going here. There is a lot of panhandling going on but they are good natured about it. The drinks are strong, the music is fantastic and the people are extremely entertaining. The is plenty of things to see, you could spend an entire day just...


More

title: New Orleans City Park, New Orleans
review_list:
This is a big park - about 1,800 acres - I got lost in the car once. But, there is certainly a lot you can do here. You can relax and watch the ducks, play golf or tennis, walk, jog, bike, visit a museum or a garden, or attend one of the many and various events that are presented in...


More  



Stopped here one afternoon and had coffee and beignets (even better than café du monde) and did not have to stand in line. City Park has gardens, art museum, park and other things to do.

This large park was built as a federal WPA project during the 1930s under FDR. It has many, many Kodak-able places for great photos. There is unusual and local food available at a cafe in the park at reasonable prices. The waitresses are friendly and not pushy.

This is a great New Orleans area. Sculpture Garden is peaceful, art well positioned, we loved the Karma scupture. Tasty food, cafe au lait and friendly folks at morning cup.

I have been during almost every season of the year and it is beautiful. I love the sculpture garden and it is perfect for family pictures.

We were staying in the Garden District, so City Park was a bit of a drive, which wasn't a big deal except we were a bit disappointed when we got there. We were looking forward to seeing the Train Garden which may have been something at one time, but is really run down now. It's located in the Botanical Gardens...


More  



there is a lot to see and do here - take a peaceful walk around the water and enjoy the birds - try the ice cream at the restaurant - great place for a picnic and it is right in the city - very large park

I highly recommend City Park as a peaceful place of respite from bustling Bourbon St. The natural beauty of magnificent Oaks and flowering bushes throughout this expansive park is enchanting and restful. On these grounds are the New Orleans Museum of Art and Sculpture Gardens. A complete cultural oasis!

A quick touring drive provided by my friend revealed a neighborhood treasure in this park. It has a fantastic storybook section for children, and a quality art museum that my be quickly toured. The park trees are amazing.

This park was a part of our Gray Line City tour and it was a pleasant surprise. I am sure the locals absolutely love the huge and well maintained park right in the city. They have a neat, reasonably priced restaurant with snacks, drinks and other goodies.

title: Preservation Hall, New Orleans
address: 726 St. Peter Street, New Orleans, LA 70116
review_list:
Authentic jazz served up by some really great musicians. It is a must for jazz lovers and anyone who enjoys live music!

A wonderful jazz venue,a history! It is a must.I preferred to pay more and have a seat from first row.I liked so much.A wonderful one hour.

Really loved seeing the old architecture in this area. I also appreciated the food, it was very tasty.

Going to Preservation Hall is a very touristy thing to do, which is not always a bad thing. If you're visiting New Orleans for the first time then it’s almost something you have to do. I paid $35 for guaranteed assigned seating in the second row at a 9pm show in the middle of the week at the end of...


More  



This place is so much fun to visit. If you have not been to New Orleans it's a great place to visit. Lot's of history and you can sit down and listen to the awesome Jazz Bands. Go there every time.

Yes, you can save a few $ if you choose to stand in line for one of the evening's sets but you not only risk being told there is no more space available just as you get entrance close but you also lose precious vacation time to waiting for an hour or longer. It is so worth it to buy...


More  



One of the highlights of my trip to New Orleans. Let me first warn - no bathrooms, you sit on benches without backs (or stand in the back) and they serve no food or drinks. You CAN bring to go (to geaux) cups with alcohol in them. We opted to be a "big shot" and paid in advance for guaranteed...


More  



It's atmospheric, certainly authentic but very much geared towards moving tourists in and out quickly. We paid $15 each for a 45 minute concert. They packed the audience into this rather small and very old hall with many standing at the back. It's uncomfortable and there are only a few metal backless benches to sit on but you have to...


More  



This little hole in the wall you'll walk right past if you're not looking for it. No booze. No food. Just the best Dixieland jazz you could ever hope to hear.
If there's a long line, go anyway. You'll get in surprisingly fast.

Preservation Hall is a gem not just to New Orleans, but to the world. It's not fancy, they do not serve food or drinks, it's just plain great live jazz.

title: The Sydney and Walda Besthoff Sculpture Garden at NOMA, New Orleans
address: 1 Collins C. Diboll Circle, City Park, New Orleans, LA 70124
review_list:
We enjoyed exploring City Park for a couple of hours on a Friday afternoon. The sculptures were interesting and varied. Our entire group enjoyed exploring the grounds. Afterwards walked over the bridge to get beignets & cafe au lair/hot chocolate.

Wow! My husband and I were very impressed with the beautiful Besthoff Sculpture Garden. The fine collection of sculpture, installed among such natural beauty, was exciting to see. We highly recommend strolling through this special place when in New Orleans.

Some nice art to gaze at in a nice little park setting - was very enjoyable, went to go to the museum on a Monday only to find it closed, but this garden was open - and very glad I went to enjoy it

We strolled through the sculpture park on a beautiful Sunday afternoon in January and were delighted by our discovery. The park is very well laid out and each sculpture has its place in the sun. We have seen work by many of these artists elsewhere, but never have we seen quality work by so many reknowned artists in a single...


More  



It was a beautiful day, which never hurts when you're visiting an outdoor area.
I'm not generally a big fan of sculpture parks, but this one has such variety that it would be difficult to not find something you like. Easy to walk by the style that doesn't appeal to you and then linger at those that do.
And if...


More  



So many and varied and beautiful sculptures. Very much worth a visit. The grounds are also great with walking paths, bridges, live oaks and more.

Not only is this a peaceful place to stroll, but the collection of sculpture is fantastic. I've seen a lot of world-class sculpture, but this was outstanding and the setting is gorgeous. And it's free! This remains a highlight of our time in New Orleans.

We live in New Orl. and prior to last weekend we had never visited the garden. We were very surprised how nice it was as well as a relaxing tour of some artist works. Recommended for locals and visitors and it free.

An amazing collection of sculptures - free admission - Louise Bourgeois, Henry Moore, and the list goes on - the Karma piece by Doh-Ho Suh alone is worth the trip - highly recommend

We have been there many times and always enjoy it. It is a must-see for our friends visiting from out of town. Especially easy after beignets and chicory coffee ar Morning Call across the road

title: RTA - Streetcars, New Orleans
review_list:
We travelled all over NOLA on the various streetcar routes. At $3 per person for a 24 hr. pass, it is a great deal. The drivers were fun and interesting and often had suggestions about places to eat, see, etc.

If you come to New Orleans and want the Flavor of the city you need to ride the street Cars.Ride Down St Charles and around the riverbend to see the Great houses and parks.Also take the Canal streetcar out to the cemeteries.

I took the street car up Canal street towards the end to see the cemeteries. It was nice way to get where I was going and see the a part of the city. Real easy to get tickets but you must have exact change.

Since there is so much to see in New Orleans around the French Quarter/Garden District/River side take advantage of this cheap method of transportation.

$3 for a Jazzy Pass to ride as many times as you care to is nice. However the trains are far apart and real crowded. They just closed down one of the lines, and did not have it posted anywhere, lucky for us we didn't get stranded.

Excellent value at $3 for 24 hours unlimited travel. Safe, clean and friendly, run into the early morning.
Only problem is they stop running during the Mardi Gras parades so be warned!

I've always loved the streetcars as a kid & the same rings true even NOW.
Downtown to Mid-city to The Cemeteries... you can ride the street car the span of the city, especially the more frequented tourist areas. Raise the window (on the non A/C) units & get a good view of the St Charles Street Mansions, eateries, Tulane &...


More  



The Green cars will take you from canal street down St. Charles Street you see beautiful homes. For $1.25 good way to see the city. Also the Green cars will drop you off near Commander Palace.

The green line that runs down St. Charles Ave. goes through the Garden District past beautiful historic homes, Loyola and Audubon park with the Aquarium and the Zoo. The Zoo has a white alligator! The green line brings you close to many great and famous restaurants, such as The Commanders Palace. It also connects to the other lines to get...


More  



RTA is a great way to get around the city. The fares start at $1.25 and you can get passes starting at $3.00. Although the city is great for walking, RTA lets you get to some of the outlying areas.

title: Jamie Hayes Gallery, New Orleans

We have two prints from Jamie Hayes including the Chili Pepper Kitty and the Smoking Club. He has so many great visions to choose from, all fabulous and original. We also bought t-shirts of the dressed alligator New Orleans Po-Boy. Classics!

I highly recommend a stop at the Jamie Hayes Gallery as you walk around the French Quarter. 'Gallery' might overstate its status; really, it is a shop, though a slick, upmarket one. They also do other products, too, including voodoo dolls and T-shirts. Plenty of eye-catching stuff to impress the folks back home.

Although we didn't make any purchases here, I thought the art work displayed was very colorful, unique, and beautiful. Worth stopping in to check out the display!

really cute shop with all kinds of fun stuff. It's that typical new orleans zany style but there are some real steals there too. Check it out if you are looking for

Frenchmen Street was an unexpected surprise. My wife and I and 2 friends were staying on Royal St. just 2 blocks from Frenchmen. We walked over to it one night since we heard all the music and saw the lights. There are numerous bars, of course. Almost all have good music and good eats. My wife and I were turned...


More  



Jazz poured out of several venues and entertainment spilled onto the street! THE location for excellent music without drunks elbow to elbow.

This is a place where the locals hang out. If you are looking for pristine restaurants this is not the area to be in. The restaurant are good and the music is great. If you are looking for a good time this an area you should out.

title: Garden District, New Orleans
review_list:
We did a self guided walking tour. Loved the beautiful homes and charm. Finished a great Sunday afternoon in the district with a fabulous dinner at Commanders Palace, a must when you are in the Garden District!

Such a beautiful place to visit while in New Orleans and the home of cemetery No.1...there are lovely book stores, cafes and quirky shops. We spent many hours just walking and driving around in the area. The houses and their landscaping are amazing. From large stately mansions to lovely but still charming smaller homes, it is just an eye opening look back into time. St Charles Street is the epicenter of the Garden District but do not pass up Magazine Street for shopping, drinks...


More  



While I was visiting my cousin in New Orleans, I took a walking tour of the Garden District. It was SO great. We had an entertaining gentleman to lead the tour and he took us all over the area. We toured the cemetery as well as the neighborhood with many beautiful homes. He pointed out Peyton Manning's family home as...


More  



saw some pretty cool peoples houses including Peyton manning also saw a house ahs(American horror story) was shot in

I so wish the cable car was running this day we visited but was able to see the railways covered with parade patrons. Not something I'd ever seen before so we took it in and had fun. The Garden District is so pretty with huge trees covering the streets. Not being from a large city we did ask about parking....


More  



There is so much more in Nola than French Quater (don´t get me wrong - you need to see those areas too!) and Garden District is one of them. Take a day to stroll around, you don´t regret it!

title: French Quarter, New Orleans
address: Canal St to Esplanade Ave, Mississippi River to N Rampart St, New Orleans, LA
review_list:
This place is interesting and worth seeing if you are in New Orleans. Don't miss the WW2 museum and make sure you check our Frenchman's street. I also recommend the battlefield.

New Orleans and its french Quarter is defiantly a place to visit once in a life time. Lovely houses, charming people and lot's of bars and restaurants... and jazz and step dance all around. Try to be there for Mardi Gras!

Have to say a little overwhelming. Lots of very drunk people. Not my cup of tea
It's okay to drink and have fun but there was too many way too drunk

We were in New Orleans only about a month before Mardi Gras and the excitement is building. The French Quarter is prettyi much the epicenter of it all. There are bars and music everywhere under normal circumstances. Now it's even more so. There's music on the streets and almost spontaneous parades and costumes happen. I cite the rather impromptu parade...


More  



Went midday with the family and walked the many old streets. Really feel like we were in another country. Hit Bourbon and Royale and all the famous streets. Not a place you want to take your young family after dark though. Bourbon turns into a party place.

Every one goes to Bourbon but much more to experience.Walk down Royal street and see the antique stores.Go to Cafe du Monde and have a Beignet

The place to be you get architecture, art, drinks, music, parades, and great food. I fell in love with the city!

This is what I know about the French Quarter;
It was founded as a military-style grid of seventy squares in 1718 by French Canadian naval officer Jean Baptiste Bienville, the French Quarter of New Orleans has charted a course of urbanism for parts of four centuries. Bienville served as governor for financier John Law’s Company of the Indies, which in...


More  



Close to all the cool pubs, restaurants and attractions. Walking distance to everywhere. We were here during Mardi Gras and oh boy party non stop at every street corner.

The drinks are strong, the music is fantastic and the people are extremely entertaining. The is plenty of things to see, you could spend an entire day just...

title: New Orleans City Park, New Orleans
review_list:
This is a big park - about 1,800 acres - I got lost in the car once. But, there is certainly a lot you can do here. You can relax and watch the ducks, play golf or tennis, walk, jog, bike, visit a museum or a garden, or attend one of the many and various events that are presented in...


More  



Stopped here one afternoon and had coffee and beignets (even better than café du monde) and did not have to stand in line. City Park has gardens, art museum, park and other things to do.

This large park was built as a federal WPA project during the 1930s under FDR. It has many, many Kodak-able places for great photos. There is unusual and local food available at a cafe in the park at reasonable prices. The waitresses are friendly and not pushy.

This is a great New Orleans area. Sculpture Garden is peaceful, art well positioned, we loved the Karma scupture. Tasty food, cafe au lait and friendly folks at morning cup.

I have been during almost every season of the year and it is beautiful. I love the sculpture garden and it is perfect for family pictures.

We were staying in the Garden District, so City Park was a bit of a drive, which wasn't a big deal except we were a bit disappointed when we got there. We were looking forward to seeing the Train Garden which may have been something at one time, but is really run down now. It's located in the Botanical Gardens...


More  



there is a lot to see and do here - take a peaceful walk around the water and enjoy the birds - try the ice cream at the restaurant - great place for a picnic and it is right in the city - very large park

I highly recommend City Park as a peaceful place of respite from bustling Bourbon St. The natural beauty of magnificent Oaks and flowering bushes throughout this expansive park is enchanting and restful. On these grounds are the New Orleans Museum of Art and Sculpture Gardens. A complete cultural oasis!

A quick touring drive provided by my friend revealed a neighborhood treasure in this park. It has a fantastic storybook section for children, and a quality art museum that my be quickly toured. The park trees are amazing.

This park was a part of our Gray Line City tour and it was a pleasant surprise. I am sure the locals absolutely love the huge and well maintained park right in the city. They have a neat, reasonably priced restaurant with snacks, drinks and other goodies.

title: Preservation Hall, New Orleans
address: 726 St. Peter Street, New Orleans, LA 70116
review_list:
Authentic jazz served up by some really great musicians. It is a must for jazz lovers and anyone who enjoys live music!

A wonderful jazz venue,a history! It is a must.I preferred to pay more and have a seat from first row.I liked so much.A wonderful one hour.

Really loved seeing the old architecture in this area. I also appreciated the food, it was very tasty.

Going to Preservation Hall is a very touristy thing to do, which is not always a bad thing. If you're visiting New Orleans for the first time then it’s almost something you have to do. I paid $35 for guaranteed assigned seating in the second row at a 9pm show in the middle of the week at the end of...


More  



This place is so much fun to visit. If you have not been to New Orleans it's a great place to visit. Lot's of history and you can sit down and listen to the awesome Jazz Bands. Go there every time.

Yes, you can save a few $ if you choose to stand in line for one of the evening's sets but you not only risk being told there is no more space available just as you get entrance close but you also lose precious vacation time to waiting for an hour or longer. It is so worth it to buy...


More  



One of the highlights of my trip to New Orleans. Let me first warn - no bathrooms, you sit on benches without backs (or stand in the back) and they serve no food or drinks. You CAN bring to go (to geaux) cups with alcohol in them. We opted to be a "big shot" and paid in advance for guaranteed...


More  



It's atmospheric, certainly authentic but very much geared towards moving tourists in and out quickly. We paid $15 each for a 45 minute concert. They packed the audience into this rather small and very old hall with many standing at the back. It's uncomfortable and there are only a few metal backless benches to sit on but you have to...


More  



This little hole in the wall you'll walk right past if you're not looking for it. No booze. No food. Just the best Dixieland jazz you could ever hope to hear.
If there's a long line, go anyway. You'll get in surprisingly fast.

Preservation Hall is a gem not just to New Orleans, but to the world. It's not fancy, they do not serve food or drinks, it's just plain great live jazz.

title: The Sydney and Walda Besthoff Sculpture Garden at NOMA, New Orleans
address: 1 Collins C. Diboll Circle, City Park, New Orleans, LA 70124
review_list:
We enjoyed exploring City Park for a couple of hours on a Friday afternoon. The sculptures were interesting and varied. Our entire group enjoyed exploring the grounds. Afterwards walked over the bridge to get beignets & cafe au lair/hot chocolate.

Wow! My husband and I were very impressed with the beautiful Besthoff Sculpture Garden. The fine collection of sculpture, installed among such natural beauty, was exciting to see. We highly recommend strolling through this special place when in New Orleans.

Some nice art to gaze at in a nice little park setting - was very enjoyable, went to go to the museum on a Monday only to find it closed, but this garden was open - and very glad I went to enjoy it

We strolled through the sculpture park on a beautiful Sunday afternoon in January and were delighted by our discovery. The park is very well laid out and each sculpture has its place in the sun. We have seen work by many of these artists elsewhere, but never have we seen quality work by so many reknowned artists in a single...


More  



It was a beautiful day, which never hurts when you're visiting an outdoor area.
I'm not generally a big fan of sculpture parks, but this one has such variety that it would be difficult to not find something you like. Easy to walk by the style that doesn't appeal to you and then linger at those that do.
And if...


More  



So many and varied and beautiful sculptures. Very much worth a visit. The grounds are also great with walking paths, bridges, live oaks and more.

Not only is this a peaceful place to stroll, but the collection of sculpture is fantastic. I've seen a lot of world-class sculpture, but this was outstanding and the setting is gorgeous. And it's free! This remains a highlight of our time in New Orleans.

We live in New Orl. and prior to last weekend we had never visited the garden. We were very surprised how nice it was as well as a relaxing tour of some artist works. Recommended for locals and visitors and it free.

An amazing collection of sculptures - free admission - Louise Bourgeois, Henry Moore, and the list goes on - the Karma piece by Doh-Ho Suh alone is worth the trip - highly recommend

title: RTA - Streetcars, New Orleans
review_list:
We travelled all over NOLA on the various streetcar routes. At $3 per person for a 24 hr. pass, it is a great deal. The drivers were fun and interesting and often had suggestions about places to eat, see, etc.

If you come to New Orleans and want the Flavor of the city you need to ride the street Cars.Ride Down St Charles and around the riverbend to see the Great houses and parks.Also take the Canal streetcar out to the cemeteries.

I took the street car up Canal street towards the end to see the cemeteries. It was nice way to get where I was going and see the a part of the city. Real easy to get tickets but you must have exact change.

Since there is so much to see in New Orleans around the French Quarter/Garden District/River side take advantage of this cheap method of transportation.

$3 for a Jazzy Pass to ride as many times as you care to is nice. However the trains are far apart and real crowded. They just closed down one of the lines, and did not have it posted anywhere, lucky for us we didn't get stranded.

Excellent value at $3 for 24 hours unlimited travel. Safe, clean and friendly, run into the early morning.
Only problem is they stop running during the Mardi Gras parades so be warned!

I've always loved the streetcars as a kid & the same rings true even NOW.
Downtown to Mid-city to The Cemeteries... you can ride the street car the span of the city, especially the more frequented tourist areas. Raise the window (on the non A/C) units & get a good view of the St Charles Street Mansions, eateries, Tulane &...


More  



The Green cars will take you from canal street down St. Charles Street you see beautiful homes. For $1.25 good way to see the city. Also the Green cars will drop you off near Commander Palace.

The green line that runs down St. Charles Ave. goes through the Garden District past beautiful historic homes, Loyola and Audubon park with the Aquarium and the Zoo. The Zoo has a white alligator! The green line brings you close to many great and famous restaurants, such as The Commanders Palace. It also connects to the other lines to get...


More  



RTA is a great way to get around the city. The fares start at $1.25 and you can get passes starting at $3.00. Although the city is great for walking, RTA lets you get to some of the outlying areas.

really cute shop with all kinds of fun stuff. It's that typical new orleans zany style but there are some real steals there too. Check it out if you are looking for

We went, late in the afternoon, to Audubon Park to watch the Egrets flying around and nesting in the trees. What a sight! This park is nice - and is surrounded by beautiful old homes and I enjoyed it. If you go to New Orleans, you must visit here for a bit of history. A for a bit of people...

I travel to New Orleans often. One of our favorite things to do before we leave New Orleans is visit the Audubon Park.

This could be a weekend excursion in itself! Pack a lunch, do a little research before you go and plan for a day of fun!

This is gem in New Orleans, this beautiful park is across from the Audobon zoo. Easy access via St Charles streetcar. Beautiful grounds with bike and walking baths. Nice for a walk or jog or to jut find a nice quiet place.

title: Immaculate Conception Church, New Orleans
review_list:
Nestled in between two buildings is this gem of a church. Very historic but well maintained. Caught the tail end of Mass and it was beautifully done. Some wonderful pictures of Mary and statues. Architecture lovers will enjoy this church.

Beautiful church to visit while in the city. The mass is always done by a Jesuit priest. Cannot miss an opportunity to view this magnificent place of worship.

We went to 4:00 pm Mass on Saturday since we were dining at Domica right across the street and the Mardi Gras parades were closing Canal Street to traffic and making it difficult to get out of the French Quarter. The church is lovely and well maintained and worth a vissit.

As the other reviews have already describe this is a very beautiful church and a must stop for all Catholics.

terrific old cathedral. beautifully preserved and well worth visiting -- especially loved the magnificent stained glass.

Attended mass here with the locals. Very nice heart warming, comfortable and welcoming. They were very nice and the church was beautiful.

I didnt stop to go inside this church, but I was taken back by the beauty of the architecture. It's located down a side street off of Canal. Take a second and visit it just to see it.

The historical looking church makes you stop and just take in its beauty. There was so much architecture to observe and holy portions of church. It was amazing. The wedding ceremony was of course wonderful and the churches interior and exterior just added to its Beauty

This is my favorite cemetery in all of New Orleans. I have a family plot here, but it is the least ornamental one in the whole place. I love the unique markers and the history.

It's an amazing site to see all these tombs have withstood the test of time and "Hurricane Katrina". It's a nice little piece of history.

I wrote a college English paper on this cemetery. It is a lovely place packed with history and people who molded the face of New Orleans. It IS a cemetery but it is definitely one of our best! Take along a cold drink so you can take your time viewing the site.

Because of the high water table common in ground burials are not used in South Louisiana. Some elaborate tombs were erected in the 19th century and the most beautiful of them are in Metairie Cemetery. This cemetery is located at the end of Canal Street admidst the tangle of cemeteries but to the left under the I-10 overpass. It is...

WOW I WENT NUTS OVER THIS CEMETERY. I hadn't known of this one till we visited the second time but it was huge and magnificent. Nestled among the upscale shops and restaurants along vibrant Royal Street in the French Quarter is a collection of historic buildings, courtyards and galleries that present a visitor with totally different experience than the celebratory norm. check the website for current exhibits, usually something of historical interest, recent exhibit related to New Orleans slave trade was excellent

title: Blaine Kern's Mardi Gras World, New Orleans

review_list:
I brought my Girl Scout troop here. The guide was amazing and let the girls explore and take a ton of photos. During MG season is the best. All of the floats are in there getting the finishing touches.

They have all your Mardi Gras needs here. Check it out you won't be disappointed. We had a really good time and it reasonable.

I wondered in and out of many stores in the Mardi Gra vicinity, and this store reall had all the decor I wanted to decorate my home in the memorable mardi gras masks, beads, and tinkets.

Finished and floats under construction floats also. Interesting to see how the make those huge floats and get info on Mardi Gras's Krewe's. Costumes there as well, lots of glitter. Plan to spend a few hours there. They have a place to eat for lunch and get beverages.

Visiting Mardi Gras world is so great. You get to walk around the beautiful floats that are being built for Mardi Gras and also see other projects that are being constructed. More  



Best drinks ever. Elizabeth is fun and informative. A great experience for locals as well as tourists. A must do in N.O.!!!!!

This is a must do when in New Orleans!!!! Here for a fun weekend and just happened onto the site and thought it sounded fun! Never knew it would be so enjoyable and delightful! You wouldn't be sad.
Elizabeth is equal parts knowledgeable and hilarious. She is 1 part sass, 2 parts class, 3 parts surprise and 4 parts delight. Her tour is engaging and interesting because it's her brain child & she clearly loves her job.

The most entertaining and informative tour we took so far. Elizabeth is so animated and will teach you so many things about New Orleans wrapped in this walking tour with iconic drinks. It's so much more than learning about the cocktails you'll taste, it's a fun history of New Orleans. Don't miss it!

The cocktails were fantastic, but I was not able to drink much. Even completely sober, the tour was a delight! Great history, fantastic delivery and a real eye toward making sure everyone was happy and safe made it a phenomenal time!

You can't miss this tour. Elizabeth has such a vast knowledge of the history of New Orleans and alcohol :) And she's fun too. Also, purchase her book! It will help you decide where to check out for the rest of your stay in New Orleans!

review_list:

Tour around French Quarter while listening to stories about various landmarks. She touches on voodoo, vampires, and zombies to name a few.

Great tour of French quarter and cemetery. Tour guide was super friendly and knowledgeable. No voodoo (except for a little prayer thing at Marie Lavueax's tomb). Would recommend.

In New Orleans for Mardi Gras. Our first time here. The Voodoo Bone Lady made the tour fun and kept it interesting with her way of passing on ghostly history. I recommend her for any tours while in New Orleans.

My friends and I came in for a bachelorette party, and to celebrate Mardi Gras. We wanted to also learn some New Orleans history, while in town. The Voodoo Bone lady was excellent!!!! Fantastic tour!! Loved every minute of it. Had the wonderful bone lady guiding us and SHE was great. Learned so much and she was so patient with my dumb questions. Took the tour during the busy Mardi Gras season, had a GREAT TIME!! We had the honor of having the Bone Lady herself give the tour! Had a quick, but awesome tour of the French Quarter & then cemetery tour. Definitely time well spent! This truly is the #1 tour in New Orleans!!

We went on the cemetery tour with a group of four. It was a great time and she went above and beyond to make recommendations on food and drinks in the area.

title: New Orleans Museum of Art, New Orleans
address: 1 Collin Diboll Circle, New Orleans, LA 70124
review_list:
We spent a couple of hours viewing the collection. An interesting collection. The gardens are well worth walking round with some interesting sculputures.

We only had time for the sculpture garden but it was a great display of modern and ancient art from many famous sculptors. Very engaging, edgy even , and something that broadens your knowledge and spurs your imagination. Wonderful creativity on display for the curious and imaginative. Get away from the crowds and Bourbon Street and see this for a...


More  



The collection has a bit of everything: Italian Renaissance to modern photography. There are a few Impressionists of interest and some period furniture. It is set in a nice park easily reached by public transportation. There is a sculpture garden and a nice cafe.

It costs $10 per adult to get in and I spent about 2 hours in the museum. This included reading most of the available information for the art. I think roughly a third of both the second and third floors were closed. It had a nice mix of media and various art movements. The flow of the place was awkward...


More  



My husband and I spent a wonderful afternoon in beautiful City Park at the NOMA and Gardens. Though limited in Impressionism and Modern Art, I thought the varied collections to be very impressive and the Tim Youd-100 Novels special exhibit interesting and exciting to see. Definitely worth a visit.

This is a much smaller art museum that others like the Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Art Institute of Chicago, the National Gallery, the MOMA, etc. It is three floors, and we were able to see it all in about 3 hours (where it takes days to see some other art museums). There are some nice pieces by Monet, one...


More  



NOMA is a beautiful building with a nice collection American and European artists, especially French. It has some nice Degas pieces, possibly because Degas lived in New Orleans for a time. Local Louisiana artists are well represented. It is also host to some excellent special and traveling exhibitions.
For me, the best part of the museum its sculpture garden. Taking...

The home collections are beautiful, but catch the road shows to go with it and your day will not be a waste!

Traveling with a wheel-chair bound child, the NOMA was a perfect place to spend a few hours. Beautiful art in an accessible setting provided a lovely time together.

The museum is quite a way outside of town. It is in the city park in a beautiful building. The space is very nice. Although there is some very nice art, the museum has a somewhat tired and dated feel to it. It could use a major facelift. Rather than concentrating in a few areas and doing that well, the...

Find a reason to attend a performance here just to get inside and see the beautiful restoration work that was done to this theatre. title: Mercedes-Benz Superdome, New Orleans
review_list:
We attended and Saints football at the Superdome. It was very clean and well maintained. Since we were in the "nosebleed" seats, we did not have much leg-room, and the steps up to the upper sections are very steep, which made me a little nervous, especially going down them since I am afraid of heights. We had an excellent view...


More  



My family and I went to a Saints game at the Superdome. It was so much fun, this is a beautiful stadium!! We had plaza level seats which were great, and there are TV's overhead to catch the replays and other stuff. Easy to get to concessions and foot. Loved it!!!

This is a wonderful place where Saints play & very family oriented place to plan - Right in the middle of New Orleans downtown close to all the fun places

The Superdome has renovated the bathrooms in recent years, and the fares at the concession stands have been upgraded. The concourse can be rather cramped during sold-out events, but thats to be expected.

So convenient to downtown and the French Quarter. Amazing building with very pleasant and professional staff. Every Super Bowl should be played here.

The Superdome looks awesome. It's not as busy as the French Quarter unless there's a game but it's nice to see it restored.

Went to see NFL's game Titans X Saints. Very organized, AC, lots of options for food and drinks. Incredible sound and huge complex.

We like going to NFL games here. There is always a great band playing outside, and plenty of places for beer and food outside as well. Prices inside for beer and food are steep!

I didn't have enough time to visit the superdome but I have a great view of the dome from my hotel room in Hyatt. Its amazing!

We went to see a Monday night NFL game, wearing opposing team colors. Fans were a lot of fun, all were friendly and had a lot of fun!

title: Magazine Street, New Orleans
review_list:
you can get almost any kind of food you want on this street. Take the bus and stop and eat and shop all day. It could take you a couple of days to see and do everything on this street. very fun thing to do

Magazine Street is a few miles long but most of the little shops and boutiques are only on a couple of miles of it. The area is cute with some interesting architecture, it's very safe to walk, and has some interesting shops to visit.
A few places I hit while I wandered (I don't remember all the names), are Sucre...


More  



Stayed at 330 Magazine St. at the St. James Hotel. It was central to everywhere that we wanted to go.

Not worth the walk unless looking for great food! the stores were very expensive but i do recommend exploring for great food options and variety

Do not spend all your time in NOLA in the Quarter! Get yourself to Magazine Street and explore the many eclectic neighborhoods it has to offer. Shops, stores, bars and restaurants galore all along this Garden District and Uptown thoroughfare. Starting about the 2000 block and working your way out all the way to 6000 block you will find many...


More  



So much to see...great architecture........interesting shop types to explore.......and great shopping. I suggest during the visit take time to sit rest, eat to build up energy to continue exploring and stop at Sucree for a cold drink to accompany the sweet dish

While the French Quarter is all about tourists the Magazine District has a feel of a neighborhood market. Sure there are antique shops and the like but there are eateries and pubs and ..... The 19th century architecture is adds to the charm. Take the tram to the garden district and at the first cemetary stop get off and walk...


More  



Enjoyed the shops on Magazine. Great place when the weather is nice to enjoy the unique shops and restaurants.

We spent about 3 hours strolling up magazine street into the garden district. There are some unique shops & restaurants to check out.

I was kind of disappointed in this street. I guess I had higher hopes. There are shops and restaurants but they are all quite pricey. We ate at a Mexican restaurant and the drinks were very expensive.

title: Ogden Museum of Southern Art, New Orleans
review_list:
Ogden is a very attractive museum with a collection that does a nice job of displaying Southern art. They cover it with admirable depth and breadth. It should be enjoyed for how well it serves its mission, which is very well.
I liked the photo exhibits and the ones dealing with social conflict.
It should be visited.

The Ogden Museum which is near the World War II Museum is another must-see. They have paintings and decorative arts in the permanent collection and special shows of southern and Louisiana arts. The building is modern and beautiful and is a treat for art lovers.

I love museums and I love southern art so this was a natural fit for me! If you can get there before the Michael Mead exhibit ends February 28, GO! His cathartic, post-Katrina works are provocative and disturbing, just as good art should be. I also particularly loved the Benny Andrews works and the Self Taught, Outsider and Visionary exhibit...


More  



This museum has many interesting pieces to view. I'm not sure I liked all of it, but I liked most of it. It is a short walk from the WWII museum and next door to the Confederate museum. I feel like it offers something different than most art museums.

I came to see the Mead exhibit and wasn't disappointed. 5 floors with different mediums, and only $12.50 and worth every penny. Lovely cashier instructed me to start from the top and work my way down (there are stairs and elevators), and she was right. I went on a Saturday afternoon and it was basically empty, it's probably busier with...


More  



Five floors of art ranging from photography to painting to sculpture, from outsider artists to more classically trained pieces including George Rodrigue ( a good old boy from New Iberia) the later painter of the Blue Dog showing his Cajun roots.

The Ogden Museum of Southern art is great if you want to get the feel for the southern culture and style of southern artist. It cost $12.00 dollars to enter but worth it. they had some amazing and interesting displays.

We loved our visit last weekend! Beautifully considered exhibitions and permanent works. Loved seeing southern visionary holdings...works many of which I'd only seen via the photographs previously. Great store too and to Kristen for her kind assistance...all curators...even the security guards were welcoming and engaged!

The Ogden Museum is billed at the largest museum of Southern Art, and that might very well be true. The museum is a very modern 4-story structure across the street from the World War II museum and Contemporary Arts Center. It is also next to the Confederate/Civil War museum near Lee Circle.
The museum is actually fairly new, having opened...


More  



My friend was more interested in going than I was. I'm not an art gallery fan generally. At first I was put off by the 4th floor photography of young southern men in Alabama. I thought photography of my life experience would be similar (a bunch of photographs of different young life... common experiences) but that is only the beginning...


More

title: French Market, New Orleans
address: Decatur St, 1100 North Peters, New Orleans, LA 70116
review_list:
We recently visited New Orleans and one of our favorite, and almost daily visits was to the French Market. It provided an opportunity to taste, explore and interact with multiple New Orleans vendors, restaurants and shops. We were also blessed to meet wonderful tourists and locals. One of our favorite restaurants was Meals from the Heart Cafe. The proprietors were...


More  



If you're looking for the typical souvenirs, many which you can find along Bourbon Street, buy them at the French Market. They will be cheaper. There are also local artists there that have some great stuff that's easy to transport as well, like prints from their original artwork and other handmade items.
Tip, if you don't want to spend any...


More  



I love the French Market- it is one of my favorite stops. I like taking cash with me on this shopping trip bc a lot of the vendors prefer it and i hate using ATM's with extra fees if I can help it. Plenty of things to buy and do here in this area and close to everything.

Good food and a great place to get a souvenir at a reasonable price. You can even deal your price with many vendors

On our first day strolling about, we came upon the French Market. My interest piqued and in we went. I was not disappointed at all. It was lots of fun with vendors of all sorts selling their stuff. We had our first Snow Ball and it was yummy. I also bought a beautiful braided bracelet for our daughter and the...


More  



The French market in Nola is a fun way to pass a couple hours. It's a good market but not great, a lot of what's in there is commercial junk but there are also treasures to be found and good food to be had. You just have to seek out the local stuff. Many of the stalls are repetitious as...


More  



If you visit New Orleans you must visit the French Market! It's the largest Flea market full of artists , vendors, Jewelry makers, etc etc.... Best Shucked Oysters!
I met Yem this artist who oil paints your first or last name using a sponge and oil paints !
Awesome place !!!
Must do !

French Market, broadly, stretches from the Joan of Arc statue to the Old Mint building, along Decatur and N.St.Peters St.
It has restaurants, shops and lots of vendors selling produce and food. At the north end, there is the Flea Market that has lots of tourist items like t-shirts and jewelry, etc.
There is also a Farmers Market every Wednesday...


More  



The French Market, not to be confused with the French Quarter, where it is located, is nothing but a collections of T shirt vendors and trinkets. So unless this is what you are looking to locate, your precious time is better spent elsewhere

Took the Riverfront Streetcar to the Ursulines Station (actually we missed the stop and rode by - but then switched cars at the next stop and rode back) and happened across the French Market. Has great food - from various vendors - seafood, gator on a stick, yummy deli sandwiches - you are going to be able to find something...


More

title: Louis Armstrong Park, New Orleans
address: 901 North Rampart Street, New Orleans, LA
review_list:
The park is double the size of NY Central Park however the food centre is small. We were on a tour bus and they were another tour bus when we got there plus the other visitors and there were no place to sit and we waited 30 mins for coffee and beignet and had to abandon our spot because the...


More  



Seeing Louis Armstrong Park was one of the things I really couldn't miss when we were in NOLA. I'm so glad we got to see it. First the art in that park was amazing, every piece is so meticulous. There's so much beauty in this park. We stopped in at Dreamy Weenies right across from the park and then toured...


More  



Nice park to hang out in. There was a music festival there when we went. Had a great time hanging out.

We stumbled on this park looking for parking for Bourbon St. It was nice to walk around and look at the statues, bridges over the water, and scenery just a few blocks from the craziness of Bourbon St.

We were on a segway tour and saw a great wedding happening at the park. Location brought back great memories of Louis Armstrong. Great place to visit.

such a beautiful park. very tranquil , peaceful walk with great artwork throughout. very peaceful and relaxing

It was interesting to see this small park in between the French Quarter and the Treme. The statues are very interesting and the fountains are nice.

SCULPTURES ARE FULL IN DETAILS!!!!! No public restroom was noted.Due to needs, my park visit was short as my hotel was near by. Some attention is needed in the park for upkeep.

We went with a tour guide to this beautiful park. We learned about the history and how many years ago people would use it on Sundays to have a picnic and spend time with their families. Very beautiful and clean park.

Well, we went there and there was nothing special to see... But we were lucky to see the marching jazz band and the dixie funeral. Besides you can skip it unless you are huge fan of Louis Armstrong and have a feeling that you would be a traitor not to come ;)

title: Backstreet Cultural Museum, New Orleans
address: 1116 Henriette Delille, New Orleans, New Orleans, LA 70116
review_list:
This museum is an absolute delight.
By itself the array of ornate Mardi Gras Indian costumes and related paraphernalia, including imagery of jazz funerals, is something to behold. But the guided tour makes everything come alive. The sweat and toil of the costume making, the parading, the critiquing and the hierarchy – all give a greater understanding of this significant...


More  



If you got a taste of the Indians from HBO's Treme or aren't in town when they are parading, then get over to the Treme to see Mr Francis' collection and talk with him about the history of the Indians and the costume artistry. Nice sample of Second line costumes and information as well.

Its a small place, costs $8 cash only. But we were surprised to see so many parade costumes, and the person who made them. They are very beautiful and amazing! Worth the trip!

This is a quaint, small museum filled with Mardi Gras Regalia and a great opportunity to learn about the history of Indians and their roll in NOLA history. Nice visit for the family. It's small so you can do the tour in an hour.

This wonderful museum is indispensable to any visit to New Orleans. It shows the roots of the culture, especially the music culture, based in Carnival traditions like Mardi Gras Indians, Skull& Bones gang, and Baby Dolls.

If you have any interest in the Indian costumes and culture, this place is a must. With luck, the young woman - great granddaughter of one of the queens - will give you a very informative tour of the place with detailed information about the tribes and their customs.

You will be blown away to get some insight into the parade krewes especially if you are visiting during the year that ISN'T Mardi Gras. Won't take long but worth the visit!!

Very Interested Museum about the Second Lines and the Mardi Gras Indians.
Do not hesitate to go and visit the Blackstreet Museum, you will learn a lot about the story of the Second Line Brass band and the Mardi Gras Indians of New Orleans.
Robert who will be your guide will give you some good tips about the events in...


More  



The creation of one man, dedicated to both memorializing and preserving the remarkable traditions and atmospheres of the 'hood against gentrification and generational change, this small museum offers a fascinating picture of and insight into the arts and cultures it represents.

If you are interested in authentic New Orleans culture, this museum is a must! A true gem and a powerhouse of knowledge tucked away in the Tremé neighborhood, the Backstreet Cultural Museum is a short walk from most French Quarter hotels and features a fabulous collection of Mardi Gras Indian suits and Social Aid & Pleasure Club and Brass Band...


More

title: St. Augustine Church, New Orleans
review_list:
We went to the 10AM mass. The choir and band were great and the sermon down to earth. The Parishoners were very open to visitors. The Church is only a block up from the French Quarter. We walked and it seemed plenty safe to us. Definitely visit the tomb of the unknown slave on the right side of church (if...


More  



We went to St Augustine Church for Christmas Eve Mass and were not disappointed. The choir and band were wonderful. The people in the church were so friendly and accepting. Enjoyed the mass a lot. Thank you for letting us join in the celebration

Does not matter what religion you are a visit to St Augustine is just what the soul needs. It is a traditional Catholic mass with a great choir - full band and great piano - at Communion all religions are welcome to come for a blessing. This is a real dose of real New Orleans and the great people of...


More  



I had the pleasure of attending a free gospel concert in St. Augustine Church recently. The concert was part of New Orleans' free holiday concert series. Beautiful church said to be the oldest black Catholic Church in the United States. The concert was fun and beautiful, but was overshadowed by the beauty and history of St. Augustine itself.

Plenty of history to take in. I recommend trying to get a guide to give you a tour and let you in on a little of the history.

On a very wet Sunday morning we went to St. Augustines to hear the choir, but we got so much more. Having read reviews on this forum, we got there early to make sure we got a seat. Maybe the rain kept people away, but the church was only about a quarter full. The first thing Rev Mulenga did was...


More  



The church is beautiful and the service moving. Wonderful choir and energetic priest who gave a sermon with the theme "Be a Christian". After mass we enjoyed looking round the church and then we asked where to get breakfast and were directed a few blocks to Buffa's where we had a splendid breakfast with a five or six piece jazz...


More  



This lovely, welcoming parish church features great music in a lovely older venue. The homily was awesome, and we enjoyed the service very much. The hospitality of the parishioners was especially memorable.

Having grown catholic, nowadays I'm not a religious person. I say this because we went looking for a gospel mass experience from a respectful point of view, not a usual sunday mass.
The music, sang from the heart, sure made its way to mine. All songs made the procedure longer than a usual mass (it ran maybe for an hour...


More  



Raised by free black parishoners in the Treme neighborhood this ancient church is showing it's age but plans are afoot to restoring it.

title: Louisiana State Museum (The 1850 House), New Orleans
address: 523 St Ann Street, Lower Pontalba Building, Jackson Square, New Orleans, LA 70116
review_list:
I think entry was around $6 so it was totally worth it. I was the most interested in the Hurricane Katrina stuff and found it fascinating. The upper level was the history of Mardi Gras which I'm still confused about but interesting nonetheless. If you are in Jackson Square stop in and check it out. I don't know if I...


More  



Visited this museum at Jackson square. I mostly did the Katrina exposition. I liked it but after the spectacular WW II museum this one is a bit too ordinary for me, no matter how sad, depressing and hopeful the topic is

The museum part was closed when we visited, but we explored the gift shop and the staff was helpful answering questions.

We learned so much about NOLA visiting this place! It's worth the money to visit. Cost is less than $10 per person. Just takes a couple of hours to take it all in. Nice afternoon excursion.

We just went into the Presbytère. There are multiple museums. In this one we saw the Katrina and Mardi Gras exhibits. They were both excellent and the entrance fee was quite reasonable.

The Louisiana State Museum has a number of fascinating properties. I got to see the Mint which has great jazz exhibits and the Cabildo which has a great exhibit on the history of rock n roll in Louisiana.

Enjoyed visiting this museum. Very interesting and educational displays. It is a self guided museum so you can take your time. The price is only $6.00. If you purchase a ticket to the Cabildo museum you get a 20% discount on both museum tickets. It took us about 2-3 hours to visit both museums. Both museums are located near Jackson...


More  



This place was hard to find. The location looked like it was in the Louisiana State History Museum, but when I got there, the woman at the desk said it's being renovated, then she took my admission and let me in. Not sure what that was all about. Anyway, what I saw was interesting and relevant to the city, so...


More  



My family visited some friends in New Orleans and spent some time on our own in Jackson Square. One of the places we visited was the Louisiana State Museum. It is open Tuesday through Sunday from 10 am-4:30 pm. When we went adults cost $6, kids under 12 were free.
We liked the entry way with a cool piece of...


More  



An affordable activity for all ages and a must see. Great history that will make you appreciate the New Orleans people.

title: Harrah's Casino New Orleans, New Orleans
review_list:
We only walked through and ate at the "Oyster Bar", which does not appear to be on Trip Advisor and I can understand why!! We should have guessed when it wasn't busy that we should have avoided it. The food was all deep fried, processed junk in my opinion, and the service and attitude of many of the "staff" 'sucked'...


More  



I have been to many casinos and this one rates in the mid range. I have never noticed a lot of people winning money on my visits. One of the advantages of this casino is that you can order a drink from your slot machine and don't have to wait and "hope" someone will come by and ask if you...


More  



Have a great time at Fulton alley part of the Harrahs complex
Great cocktails a lot of family fun you can go get your gamble on all within walking distance great restaurants right nearby as well

Harrahs continues to be great. The gaming and service are better than ever and even during Mardi Gras they did not feel like they couldn't handle the crowd

Casino right in the heart of things in NOLA.
Mega amounts of slots. Poker tournament was in process at the time we were there. Was an interesting watch for a bit.
Casino is impressive... has a Bourbon Street theme.

We stop by when we need a break from sightseeing. We usually try to get a room here as well but they are usually full. This is convenient to the street car line and the rest of the tourist areas.

Lots of fun. Right near Canal Street. No smoking inside. Not far from the Ferry entrance and street car.

With no smoking allowed, the atmosphere is fresh and exciting. They is plenty of food and drink and a wide variety of games to play.

Harrah's is the only casino in the city i have been to and feel safe inside, but if you stay outside of the casino my wife and I have a problem walking down the street to and from another one of their properties to sleep.

Wonderful experience at the casino because the atmosphere was friendly,beautiful, and smoke-free. We will definitely come back to visit.

title: Beauregard-Keyes House, New Orleans
review_list:
Worth visiting - has great history. House plus collections and a garden. Well worth a tour. Across street from the historic church/nunnery so plan time to do both!

A tour of this house is a great introduction to the different architectural styles in the French Quarter and greater New Orleans. The tour packs a lot into a short amount of time.

A very short tour with only two people and the guide, it was more eerie than enjoyable. Of all the things I enjoyed in New Orleans, this is one I wish I had passed up on. Often I enjoy historical tours and architecture, but this was a lackluster experience.

This is a perfect example of what it was like for a Creole family of wealth to live like in the early 1800's before the Americans began arriving. It will show you the gentility of the period and how their society was of all importance to them and New Orleans as it developed to be a premier port city in...


More  



The guided tour of the house and grounds was excellent - the best I attended in New Orleans. The guide was informative and friendly - he is a great example of southern hospitality.

The tour in this house is modest and matter of fact but the spectacular comes from the visitor gaining understanding of how people lived 200 years ago. A must do for everyone who wants to learn how well to do people lived in the New Orleans of two centuries ago

Had the opportunity to visit this historic home, and had the luxury of a private tour. Very interesting history, and a truly beautiful home. Glad we made the decision to visit.

If you love to visit older homes with antiques, then this would be great. If you're like us who just want to visit things, it wasn't all that interesting.

I saw this home while on a self-guided tour hosted by the Friends of the Cabildo (FOC) and was delighted. It's a beautiful home with period furniture and decorations. We were fortunate to have been guided by a very knowledgeable lady in period dress.

This house is across from the old Ursuline Convent. Our guide was very knowledgeable about the house and residents. He encourage my daughter to play the 18th century piano.
Very enjoyable couple of hours

title: Old River Road Plantation Adventure, New Orleans
address: 2041 Canal Street, New Orleans la, New Orleans, LA 70112
review_list:
We booked the Evergreen/Oak Alley plantation tour and the swamp tour before leaving on our trip. The cost was approx. $350 for three of us. The night before our tour the company confirmed the trip with us and then picked us up at the hotel the next morning around 7:30a.m. Our tour driver was wonderful! He was very full of...


More  



Each one is unique and has its own architecture and style as well as its particular history,but all are fascinating. Tours are possible in many houses and gardens and some have restaurants and rooms to rent. You can't understand the South unless you see how they lived and worked before the War between the States.

This was one of my highlights when we visited NOLA. Our tour guide, Jacques, picked us up promptly at our hotel. There was only a total of 8 of us taking the tour this day and it was wonderful! Jacques was very knowledgeable, and shared information continuously. There was never a lack of information. He welcomed questions and seemed to...


More  



I selected this tour company because of the opportunity to get off the beaten path, take a more scenic drive, and be in a smaller group. We did the two plantation and swamp tour package and very glad we did. Our tour bus driver gave an excellent narrative of what we would see, the history of the area, his personal...


More  



Our guide, Richard was the best. He shared so much information with you that you felt that you were a real part of the plantation experience and what it has meant to the development of the area and what it continues to mean. Oak Alley is one offering that is not to be missed. You could really spend a day...


More  



We toured with Old River Road To the plantations, Oak Alley, The San Francisco and then the swamp tour. The lunch provided was great. Our guide Jacques was great!

We did the Oak Alley and Laura Plantations and swamp tour. We had excellent customer service and felt taken care of during our tours. Our tour guide was very prompt. He shared a lot of history with us to and from the plantations.
Both plantations were worth visiting. They are both very different and give a good overview of what...


More  



This was a long day but good. The van picked us up at our hotel. The driver was knowledgeable and efficient. We went first to Oak Alley plantation, had a tour there and then to the Laura plantation, my favorite, another tour. Then lunch, the restaurant had all our orders, food came fast and was okay. Then off to a...

Originally, my husband and I were supposed to take the Oak Alley/Evergreen Tour. However, because of filming at evergreen, we had to vist Laura instead. No regrets! From booking to ending the tour, this company is seamless in their handling of this tour. Nick, our guide, was extremely knowledgeable on numerous subjects regarding the plantations as well as the city....


More  



I did the Plantation/Swamp combo tour. It was great to check out the plantations and hear all about life in Louisiana. It was also very sad to hear about the treatment of the slaves but informative. We visited Oak Alley and Laura Plantation. We wanted to see Evergreen but the night before the agency informed us that it was closed....
