title: Canal Street / Algiers Ferry, New Orleans
review_list:
A round trip ride across the Mississippi River on the Canal?Algiers ferry is a great way to view the CBD and French Quarter from a different angle and in a very relaxing way. The river at this point is 150 feet deep.

Take the ferry back and forth across the river. It's only $2 each way and you get to see the city in the best way possible. It's strange, but you have to get off the boat at Algiers, got down some steps to get back on. I don't understand why they make you do this, but they do.

$2 each way for a few minutes ride over the river to Algiers Point. Took some great pictures of the skyline and had a bit of a wonder around before coming back. A great way to spend and hour.

We were hard pressed for time and rushed to the ferry terminal for the last ferry[ 9:15 pm] out, so we could not get off on the Algiers side and had to turn around at Algiers and return on the same last ferry back. The original plan was to get off at Algiers and explore the historic neighbourhood of the...


More  



It was cool and windy when we were there. We did get to see several ships coming and going. We had some great views of the original city of New Orleans.

A good way to cross the river to Algiers, The cost is $2 each way and $1 for seniors each way. Their are ramps so you don't have to go up the many step to board the ferry.

It takes only about 10 minutes to cross the river on the ferry but it's a lovely way to do it. Costing only about $2 (I can't remember exactly but it was super cheap, and less for seniors) per person, you can enjoy the view of the city from the water and feel the rush of the river against the...


More  



Believe it or not, but once upon a time there wasn't much touristy stuff going on in NOLA. As recently as the seventies, a trip to the foot of Canal for a snowball and the ride to Algiers was a big deal.
Thankfully, the ferry is still there. It's been operated by the government since the 1800's, allowing access to...


More  



Four of us took the ferry from the foot of Canal Street to Algiers just before sunset. The views of boat traffic on the river and the New Orleans skyline were great. Many photo ops! We then took a walk in old Algiers and sat for a while on the levee to just watch the activity on the river. There...


More  



A friend recommended the ferry as an alternative to parking in the city. This is the best advice ever! We parked in the lot by the ferry run by some locals. (It cost $10.00 on the weekend and $5.00 on the weekdays....and much more over Mardi Gras) Then we boarded the ferry and 8 minutes later we were in down...


More

title: NOLA Tropical Winery, New Orleans
address: Outlet Collection at Riverwalk, 500 Port of New Orleans, Suite 144, New Orleans, LA 70130
review_list:
Soo good.. a must try! We've had it multiple times! Yummy . We keep coming back for more. Love the wine smoothies.

Michelle was awesome, bubbly and didn't miss a beat. Service personally all on tack and oh yeah your wines and smoothies were good too 😀

Great wines, but way better when Michelle's pouring!!!
Try the dreamsicle slushie - again, way better when Michelle's pouring.

Wine smoothies to die for and Michelle just keeps them pouring!!!! Love this place!!!!
Free wine tastings as well! This is my third year in NOLA and never miss a stop here😉

Can't believe the wine smoothies they are amazing loved ever mintue. The staff is the best Erica you will be missed. Thanks it was a blast and recommend it to anyone that comes the Nola.

You have got to try their smoothies!!! Great place to unwind and meet people before your cruise!!!!!

My friend and I arrived in New Orleans early so we couldn't check in until 5PM. We decided to explore and went to the Riverwalk Outlet and had lunch. We decided to look around at the stores and came upon Nola Tropical Winery. We decided to pass by but my friend said, "free wine tastings" and I was sold!!! Michelle...


More  



I have visited Nola tropical winery 3 different times. I have enjoyed it each time. The server was knowledgeable and friendly. Love all the different wines. Stop in you will enjoy it

The Hurricane Cabernet smoothie was absolutely amazing!!!! So amazing that we shopped and went back to buy the mix and wine so that we could make it at home!!!!

Such great service came back for more! Tasted all favors ! Everyone was 😋😋 i decided on the peach sangria but the who dat was my second

title: Frenchmen Art Market, New Orleans
review_list:
So, we thought this place was closed. Then about 7pm we walked by again, and it was opening. Lot's of handmade arts and crafts.

A great place on Frenchman street to take a break from the music and drinking. We were there three nights in a row. Each night had some of the same artists but also Different too. Some very unique things there to add to your decor.

While walking down Frenchmen Street, we saw beautiful white lights strung from one end of an open air market to the other brightening up the market full of people browsing and shopping. Vendors sell painted art, sculptures, quality jewelry, various parfums and more. I highly recommend the vendor Philip on St. Charles as he has a number of pleasant fragrances...


More  



This is a cute, fun place to find homemade goods.
The walk there was a little sketchy, but there were a lot of police along Frenchmen Street. Once we got to the Art Market we felt safe. It was brightly lit.
There were a lot of unique goods there made by local artists. This is a good place to go...


More  



Don't go out of your way for this. I made a point of going here and really wanted to like it. It is all local art and some of it is good but most of it is just average. It's a nice little spot, off Frenchman Street, well lighted and there's nice seating available. It's only open at night and...


More  



I have never visited New Orleans and not stopped into Frenchmen Art. I always enjoy to see what they have received since the last visit

If you collect the kind of stuff sold at craft fairs, the Frenchmen Art Market is for you. Since I have no appetite for this kind of stuff, I would rate this just average. I'm not good at distinguishing good stuff from bad.

Fun place to cruise around and look at local art. Buy something! Shop local! It had something for everyone. Jewelry, paintings, clothing...there are places to sit and watch the crowd or for a photo opp.

A really beautiful spot on a clear evening. There was photography, painting, t-shirts, glass, and so many others.
A really great spot to browse in between dinner and music.

Great collection of local art. Lots of jewelry. Even had clothing and larger art pieces and a group of performers. The artists were really nice and eager to talk about their craft. One of my favorite things I did this trip.

title: Hermann-Grima House, New Orleans
address: 820 St Louis Street, New Orleans, LA 70112
review_list:
Being inside the residence, you will get a true feeling of what life would have been like back in the early 1800's. It is a picture of wealth and refinement during a period that can only be appreciated through being in the home and enjoying all it has to offer. You shouldn't miss a visit to this living history.

We learn a lot about the way families lived in the early years of New Orleans. The docents were well informed.

We wanted to see a typical historic house in New Orleans and this one certainly had the potential to have its interesting history revealed. But the tour guide who showed us round rattled everything off in record-speed time and we were back outside in 35 minutes. She asked for questions in each room and every time we asked one, we...


More  



We were unable to tour the inside due to it is privately owned but going on the ghost tour and hearing the history of the home and the owners that had experiences from it . Im just tempted to get a view of the inside of it.
Daisy C.

This tour allows you to see the early lifestyle and understand the typical Creole attitudes about the importance of family and the connections of that attitude to their home building. This inexpensive tour was surprisingly informative and interesting. Our tour guide, a student herself, was friendly and personable. I learned several things about American and French architecture that I hadn't known before.

We have been to New Orleans many times and had missed out on the Hermann-Grima House. The tour guide was very informative! The furnishings are appropriate for the era of the inhabitants. Many items were owned by the Hermann and Grima families. My favorite part was touring the kitchens! The museum employees still use them!

If you are looking for time to kill this is a great place to visit. Tucked in the middle of the French quarter just steps away from bourbon street, this house which was occupied by two families and then a women's boarding house is a step back into another time. Most of the furnishings are from the original owners or...

We went on a Thursday which come to find out is the best day to visit. It is cooking day at the house. Out back there were two ladies cooking in the old slave kitchens. They were using the original fireplace, dutch oven and something like a stove, but not really. It smelled wonderful and was so interesting. Our only...

This house is one of two that you can visit that if you visit one, you get a discount on the second. The other house is the Gallier House. They are both worth a visit, even on a rainy day. Both guides did an excellent job. They are within easy walking distance from each other and are fairly close to...

title: Bourbon Street, New Orleans
review_list:
A very lively and quirky place to visit. Lots of bars and great restaurants. Lovely old houses... one prettier than the other. Great little stores selling jewelry and antiques. The whole french quarter is a place for your buckets list.

we stay on Bourbon at the Four Points, we love the location, and just walk up and down the street and take in all the sights. So much fun. lots of places to eat and listen to good music, most of the places do not charge to go in and listen to the bands.

This place impressed me both for good and bad. You can find all kinds of crazy people, drunk people, dressed up, naked, on bachelors parties, students. I'm from Rio de Janeiro, I'm not easily impressed by craziness, but Bourbon St was too much even for me. Since I was in New Orleans for the music, I prefered Frenchman st. But...

Bourbon Street is a famous street because of all the wrong reasons. It takes what makes New Orleans fun and inflates it to such levels that it exceeds bursting at the seems and is heavily inflating.

We specially flew to New Orleans to hear blues music and so we booked a wonderful hotel on the corner of Bourbon St and gues what we encoutered when we finally got there, friendly drunks and duff duff music. Bourbon Street is a one of a kind. There is nothing charming about it during the day and kids should never be there. Lots of adult only sites and things being sold. Off season travel to the great city of New Orleans was fun. Bourbon Street during off season was still very full of life. I'm sure that during Mardi Gras season it is quite crowded. We spent a few days in New Orleans before our Christmas Cruise. We stayed in the French Quarter at Place d'Arms. Great small hotel in the French quarter close to everything. For those who enjoy a variety of scenery, shopping, history and night life. Bournbon Street - French Quarter have all to offer.

I was here for the first time in July and hoped it to be slow, but (weekend) it was wild with all the bars and clubs happening. I decided to come back here for Mardi Gras (Weekend before Fat Tuesday) and it was Crazy and Unbelievable. If you are in the US for Mardi Gras - You have to come...

title: The Spotted Cat Music Club, New Orleans
review_list:
My husband and i were in town for Mardis Gras. We had to see Davis and visit this amazing venue. So glad we did. I was in heaven. Thanks Spotted Cat and Davis. Bucket list tick.

Worth stopping by to listen to good music and enjoy a beer. Unfortunately, it is very small and gets super crowded.

This is a great spot to hear new music and enjoy local beers. Not for the faint of heart, but if you've got the feeling, this is the place to be. A truly NOLA music experience and place.

There was a great jazz band on the Saturday evening that we visited, I felt we’d traveled back in time to the glory days of jazz. Good drinks. Cash only. Only complaint was the bathrooms – only one each and there was always a line. Still, a must-visit in my opinion.

The Spotted Cat is a must visit. We go on every visit. Amazing talent and a step back to the early music of New Orleans. Bring cash as they don't take credit cards.

We searched for a music spot that would cry out New Orleans and found it on Frenchman Ave. There was a great contemporary jazz band playing with a 1930s influence. Highly recommended if you want to hear sone great music in a authentic New Orleans venue.

The music at this bar was absolutely amazing and they have people dancing. The interior could be a bit nicer and cleaner.

The band playing was great. The atmosphere was good. The only issue we had was that the place is very small and there weren't many places to sit. There were chairs at the bar of course and just a row of seats along one wall with only 2 very small bar height tables. Had we been able to sit and...

We heard some wonderful music here. It was crowded but everyone was having a great time. Truly felt I had come to the right place to hear jazz!

My husband and I were there in late January on a Saturday night. There was a $5 cover, and the place was absolutely packed.... seriously shoulder to shoulder. It was a nice place to enjoy a drink and listen to good music. The people watching was great. It was right across the street from the Lafitte Guest House where we were staying.

This is a fun place make one of the best Hurricanes. This suppose to be haunted a place to visit and some Hurricanes.

Visited here one night to experience the atmosphere of an older bar. Not too impressed with the space. Supposed to have the best purple drank, but was not impressed.

A Great place

So if i had to id say that this place is way up there.

This is the first time I have visited the Erin Rose since I started going to New Orleans over 15 years ago. A friend of mine who used to live there recommended that I go and have the frozen Irish Coffee. It was so good I texted her a picture of it and brought her back some Erin Rose beads.

Recommended to us by another bartender it's small and they serve a great PoBoy in the back. Nice non-bourbon st bar

We didn't get to eat here but the drinks are great and don't miss the frozen Irish Coffee, it's one of the few places around that have it and it's way better than any frozen daiquiri.

Perfect bar for a few drinks or to enjoy watching the antics of Bourbon. Great drinks, well priced. Definitely a bar lover's bar.

Average place to visit. Average toilet. Strong drinks. Good service. Not that far from burbon st. Worth a visit if you're in need of a quieter pub

Printed a list of drinks from a website and Erin's frozen Irish Coffee was on the list. Needless to say, I went by twice on my trip to get one after waking up a little slow after nights on the town. Stop by and grab one for your morning walks around the quarter.

Loved this place, check it out, have a drink, you can't buy atmosphere like this. FYI: smallest bathroom I've ever been in

Cool neighborhood (sort of) bar filled with old neon. Good hot buttered runs and hot toddy. Great place to hang out. And enjoy killer po boys in the back until midnight. Will keep coming back!

title: Royal Street, New Orleans
review_list:
Great street artists and bands. Good vibes. Great shopping, especially liked Forever New Orleans. They had a good selection of nice NOLA souvenirs and nit the usual kitch crap you find in the other stores.

From one end of Royal St to the other, one can experience all that is New Orleans. When in the Quarter, be sure to start at one one of Royal St and enjoy the stroll.

Very Picturesque and lots of character.The antique stores and the Art stores are well worth the walk

Of course everyone talks about the famous Bourbon Street in New Orleans, but we found Royal Street to have the best restaurants, bars, and shops with a little less traffic.

Royal street is one street over from Bourbon Street. I spent most of my time there because of the great restaurants, shops and sights. You will find a lot of historical sights and things to do and see. Good for the whole family. Plus some jazz musicians like to play in the street.

Numerous interesting shops lie along Royal Street. The Visitor's Center can provide self-guided walking tour brochures that include many stops along Royal Street. Recommended stop: Café Beignet.

Though not far from Rue de Bourbon, Royal Street is a different world. Like most streets within the French Quarter, Royal Street contains restaurants, cafes, and clubs. These establishments are far more subdued than those on the neighboring streets. The street is also home to many nice Galleries and shops. The Street performers tend to be more laid-back as well.

One night on Bourbon Street is enough! Head over to Royal Street for some clean, classy fun! Great Foods, amazing bands!

There is so much to see and do on Royal Street. There are art studios, antique shops, boutiques, and live entertainment everywhere. Take some time to leisurely wander up and down the street taking in the atmosphere.

Definitely opt for this street over Bourbon Street for walks through the Quarter. Also, there are tons of street musicians at virtually all times of the day. Royal Street is one of our favorite places to walk in the French Quarter!

title: Boutique du Vampyre, New Orleans

review_list:
Perhaps we expected more based on the web story and the reviews - so we left a bit underwhelmed. However, the selection was interesting and the displays well done. The lady seemed helpful.

This was our first visit to New Orleans, and the shopkeeper was very friendly and welcoming. She even took time to recommend several other places around town that we should visit. She enthusiastically described many of the items for sale, as well.

From the moment you walk in here, it's like you're greeted by an old friend. Marita is welcoming, helpful, informative and all round, definitely awesome! There are goodies in this shop that I have never seen anywhere else - a great range of unique items with a fantastic atmosphere!

So glad that we stopped in to this quaint little shop. Yesterday I came to new Orleans with my mother and friend specifically for the charm candle that are already made for you out of all the places in new Orleans this lady was the nicest most helpful she gave us a map with some neat stuff to do I've been to new Orleans too many times to count and this...

title: Hex: Old World Witchery, New Orleans
review_list:
Psychic Carie E. was amazing!!! The staff was also very interesting and helpful. I will return during my next visit to NOLA.

Carrie was amazing and spot on!!! Truly an amazing experience! Highly recommended! If you don't do it, you'll regret it!

We are here for a girls weekend..mardi gras. Went to get psychic reading from Carrie, she was so extremely nice and comforting! Amazing experience from front desk to reading! Highly recommend this place as a part of your New Orleans experience!

So gray! So this place and Josh is a pillar of information and Anastasia was beyond helpful. We had the best time and come back every year of them!! Thank you!!

My husband and I loved Hex so much that we visited the shop two days in a row during our New Orleans visit. The staff was extremely helpful and took their time showing us what they had to offer. Products are of high quality and you can find everything you need here. I was especially pleased at the book section...

A skeptic at first, I have begun an interesting journey under the guidance of reader Elie Barnes. Ms. Barnes brings an interesting mix of passion, practicality, authenticity, and compassion to her work and throws in a good dose of experience and academia. Her readings are a true treat and I encourage others looking for a thoughtful, insightful reading to schedule...


More  



Excellent store with interesting stuff to ogle over and to buy. A bit crowded - but filled with fun stuff. There appears to be an on-site psychic (always a good thing) but she called her guest the wrong first name while we were shopping - probably too focused on the netherworld.
Recommended stop on your witchery item huntings.

This was by far the most informed group of people I meet in any of the occult stores in New Orleans. The staff was friendly and very open to discuss any topic in depth!

It's hard to take everything in because it's a little cramped inside. They have a ton of items for people interested in wicca or if your just interesting. The staff is super helpful and super nice, they make you feel comfortable. The prices are a little high but it's what you would expect in a tourist area.

Hex is a "must see" and one of my first stops when visiting New Orleans. I spent time with Elie who is an amazing spiritual advisor and a highly skilled Palm and Tarot Card reader. She was very knowledgable and quite insightful. I brought home with me candles, incense and a whole new outlook on life!

My wife & I took our son (30) and girlfriend to the cooking school - everyone loved it. The food was great and for two+ hours we learned about the history of New Orleans, the food/culture in a fun and funny experience.

We attended a Saturday morning cooking demo. The 60 guests were really entertained by our chef, and we all picked up some tips and learned some new techniques. For the price, the demo and the meal was well worth it. Highly recommend!

My wife and I have been here twice - one class with Chef Kevin, another with Chef Harriet. Both times were absolutely outstanding. title: Lake Pontchartrain, New Orleans
review_list:
The Lake Pontchartrain Causeway is the longest one in the world. It is 25 miles long! When you are in the middle you wouldn't be able to see land if it wasn't for the buildings in New Orleans - it is like being on a cruise, with pelicans flying by.
Not much fun when commuting in fog though.
They have...


More  



In the past before they built the second bridge when you crossed the 25 mile long bridge in the middle, because of the curvature of the earth you couldn't see land in any direction. If you like driving over cool bridges, this is worth the drive. It one of the longest bridges in the world, about 30 miles At a certain point you can't see land. More  



This is the worlds longest single stretch bridge spanning more than 22 miles. Except for the distant Man made building that are visible from either end , you get a feeling of driving over sea.
It is astonishingly easy to drive on the two lane highway. There are options to turn around and get back in case you decided to...


More  



On our drive to New Orleans from Ontario Canada we planned to take a small detour so we could travel on the Lake Pontchartrain Causeway. It cost $3 and it was worth it. I felt safe driving the bridge. As you get closer to New Orleans you see the skyline. Very nice view and worth the small detour.

Just loved crossing Lake Ponchartrain on the causeway - said to be one of the longest bridges in the world, if not the longest. The thing I enjoyed the most was being the middle of the bridge and not being able to see land in any direction - and for a distance of some miles. That was fun.

Lake Pontchartrain is huge and to understand just how huge it's worth driving the length of the Lake Pontchartrain Bridge or causeway. Guinness says that at 24 miles it is the longest continuous bridge in the world. For 7 or 8 miles of its length one cannot see either shore.

For the past two visits to New Orleans my wife and I have taken a walk along the south shore of Lake Pontchartrain (where Canal St. hits the lake, east of the restaurant Landry's). Found out we wanted to drive over world longest bridge. Amazing.. But look up for the police... they stood everywhere on the bridge.. so dont overspeed.

For those who can't or won't get out on the ocean. This is an other way to feel as if you are water for miles.

title: Confederate Memorial Museum, New Orleans
address: 929 Camp St, At St. Joseph's, New Orleans, LA LA 70130
review_list:
We walked here one of the weekend days we were in New Orleans, only to find that the place was closed. Very disappointed, as we were looking forward to visiting this museum!

The museum is quite small in comparison to its across the street neighbor - WWII museum. There is a short film and quite a few Confederate artifacts, plus a small gift shop.

For all the mayors feelings in this city about tearing down the statues and history of the confederates and civil war, I hope they leave this lovely little museum alone.
Tip - go straight to the back room and watch the short video first as it really helps to understand what the south had to endure.
What struck me was...


More  



We found the artifacts to be well preserved. It is important to remember that what has made us a great nation is the fact that when the wars are won we rebuild and mend. Rather than destroy the history and dignity of the people we who lost. Lee was a great general! The people who fought for the Confederacy were...


More  



Neat museum with Southern history and charm. Loved the fact that it is the South's oldest museum. If you want to see the beautiful war memorials hurry because the city is hell bent on tearing them down. They are very close to this little gem.

Small museum with real life applications. You realize this was not so long ago when the last confederate died in the 1940's.
An interesting take on life in the south and particularly NOLA
Well worth the $8 entrance fee

I think they presented the exhibits in a reasonably fair way, but you have to remember they aren't honoring saints here. Lots of interesting objects, nice little gift shop. It's sort of across the street from the National WW2 museum.

In addition to the wonderful architecture, the exhibits are most interesting. Next to Ogden Museum and WW2 Museum, so we visited all three on a rainy day. Plenty of parking.

The museum is small with a $8.00 admittance for adults. My wife and I travelled the civil war trail, called the 'Hallowed Ground' which held many museums. In comparison I felt disappointed with this museums limited artifacts. I was however, impressed with there authenticity. It is a short walk from the WWII exhibit across the street.

Having visited civil war museums in the likes of Atlanta, this one simply does not stack up in presenting an engaging journey. It does however house an extraordinary and vast collection of Confederate artifacts most specific to Lousiana, and on that basis alone worthy of a visit.

title: Tulane University, New Orleans
address: 6823 St Charles Ave, New Orleans, LA
review_list:
Just walking the campus grounds with its ancient trees is a sight to be enjoyed. It's always a pleasure to see so many young people busy between classes,talking and laughing with friends and at the same time preparing seriously for the future.

Catch the streetcar and get off at the front of campus for a nice walk down past Freret to the UC,where you can grab a bite to eat. Pretty awesome library, too.

Great program, an array of curricula, wonderful campus, great professors. If it wasn't for the many entitled students it would be perfect. I imagine that many of them are entitled because the tuition is so high.

A ride on the trolley to see St. Charles Street and the accompanying beautiful neighborhoods is not complete without walking on Tulane's beautiful campus. Be sure to see the tree that is covered with bead necklaces from the annual Mardi Gras. It shows that fun is not far away at any time at Tulane.

The Campus is nice and the trip all the way down St. Charles on the Street Car is $1.25 one way. There are places to eat at end of car turn around... The Campus is very nice and is right across the street from Auduban park.

take the st Charles streetcar and get off and just walk around. near Xavier and also by Audubon park

Beautiful campus, conveniently located. We visited with a prospective student, so we took the official tour.

A sybaritic setting next to Audubon Park and Loyola University, in the Garden District of New Orleans. Lovely buildings in a park like setting. It's an easy and inexpensive RTA streetcar ride from the French Quarter.

What an amazing place. Minutes from the French Quarter....on St Charles Street among stunning home....across from Audubon Park...the camps is so pretty with beautiful old building and lots of shady trees....

Take the St Charles streetcar and tour the Garden District to see this beautiful campus and the surrounding mansions.

title: Old Ursuline Convent, New Orleans
address: 1112 Chartres St, At Ursuline, New Orleans, LA
review_list:
I mainly wanted to go through this museum just to be able to see inside the old building. It was definitely worth seeing. The museum basically covers the history of the Ursulines and Catholicism in general in the NOLA area, which is not of particular interest to me. There was a fellow inside who was very knowledgeable about NOLA history...


More  



There are a number of historical sights to see in New Orleans, but I found this interesting (even though I have no real religious connection). It helps you understand what these young nuns went through to come here and create what they did.

The history of the Catholic orphanage here combined with access to St. Mary's Cathedral is a moving experience.

This oldest building in New Orleans provides a great overview of how the sisters of the Ursuline Convent did help with education and care for the less fortunate in the early years of New Orleans. The story of the two miracles and the large number of people that walked those hallways that got recognized by the church during and after...


More  



Go through here and capture the rich spiritual history of America. Through this place and history you will get to know and understand how God helped make this country great. You will see old structures and get the stories of those who built them and worked in them and worked for the people of this area.
If you love beautiful...


More  



My husband and I passed the convent several times while visiting New Orleans and thought it was just another convent. Were we wrong! It's the oldest building in the lower Mississippi River area. The history of the place will surprise and impress you. And the ladies who volunteer there are very informative. We went there on our last morning in...


More  



This tour was very interesting with the religious aspects of the convent. There are no tour guides, but the ladies that were volunteering were a wealth of information. Without them stepping in an talking with us, the tour would not have been good. They had a wealth of information and made it come to life for us. Be sure to...


More  



I think everyone should experience this quaint and historical place. It is run by really nice people who really want to tell you all kinds of factual stories of New Orleans. A final read and every room with antiques and pictures galore. Also check out the gift shop where you buy tickets that, it has some great jewelry and fun...


More  



Enjoyed walking through the convent and gave a nice glimpse into the past. It's a self guided tour, but the docent was very knowledgeable and loved to share what she knew. The chapel is beautiful.

There is a lot of history in this facility since it was one of only two buildings that survived the fire that burnt New Orleans to the ground.

title: Ernest N. Morial Convention Center, New Orleans
address: 900 Convention Center Blvd., New Orleans, LA 70130
review_list:
This convention center is very big and it can accommodate the really big shows. But the best part is that the city of New Orleans has provided a vibrant and exciting area around the center and it's hotels for the participants. There are well known restaurants right across the street, and the newly spruced up Julia St. area is right...


More  



Attended the 2016 American Meteorological Society Meeting here. The Convention space allowed for small to large meeting areas and plenty of common areas to bump into colleagues. Wish there were more seating options in the lobbies and hallways.

If you are attending a convention there, and they try to sell you an alligator sausage po boy, BUY IT. Plop yourself in one of those comfy chairs in the lobby and watch the traffic roll by as you eat. Good stuff!

4th year and 1 of the best ever. They do their best to accommodate the huge amount of people that descend on this annual event. Plenty of security and personal to handle this event.

I was in New Orleans on business for a week when I spent most of the daytime hours at this convention center. It is in an accessible area and has a pretty good floor plan. The food court offers a decent variety. There are hardly any recycling receptacles, however, which was a disappointment. This seems to be a wider issue...


More  



the staffers at this facility were extremely nice and helpful, going over & beyond each time i needed assistance.

Attended a big convention that used most of the convention center. Comfortable shoes are a must. You can get a fair amount of walking in going from meeting to meeting. Was disappointed with the food options at 8 am but that got better around lunch in the center.

I was an exhibitor for the 2015 Workboat Show, and I was very impressed with the facility. It is well laid out, and the food court area offers a great selection. Plenty of bathrooms, which is always a plus.

I have been in the Center 3 times, I go every time I visit NO for the Essence Fest. This is the best location to have this event because it can accommodate everything. I like its location it allows for walking from area places.

We had a 3 day convention for the 42nd annual National Association of Sporting Goods Wholesalers Expo. It was our first time at the show, and it was very successful. Met a ton of really great people.

title: Woldenberg Riverfront Park, New Orleans
address: 1 Canal St, French Quarter, New Orleans, LA
review_list:
Nice views, great location, safe area. But be prepared for the wind! Amid all the NOLA activity, Woldenberg Park is a great place to relax. This lovely green space runs along the Mississippi riverfront from around the Audubon Aquarium to around St. Philips St. near the French Market. The park has lots of areas for picnics and plenty of benches for watching the river flow by.
There are also concerts in the...


More  



This one of the few places in New Orleans that you can get up close to the Mississippi River and the ships that sail on her. Most of the Mississippi is blocked from view by the wharfs and the closest you can get is only with in one block of the river. Woldenberg Park lets you stand over the Mississippi...


More  



There is art to view, boats to watch and calm to be found. It is very clean and well maintained. A nice way to walk between French Market and Canal street.

Great spot for everyone. Families with small children, couples, people jogging, some street performers. The river was near flood stage so you really appreciate how much water and power it has. We walked from the French Quarter up to the aquarium.

Fine views of the Mississippi and of St Louis Cathedral, but as others have said it is it not really a spot to linger. Homeless...

this park extends from the aquarium to the old jax brewery near the square in the french quarter. it runs right along the mississippi river and is a flat easy stroll. you can see the big ships moving along the river or look back and have views of the city and french quarter. on weekends it is a gathering spot...

The riverboat plays cool music at like 5:30 every night. The Mississippi is wide and beautiful, barges roll along continually. What a magnificent riverfront! Every evening we would relax on the benches overlooking the Mississippi watching the ships glide down the river and the people jog and walk by. Simply beautiful, and full marks to the city of New Orleans for constructing and maintaining such a beautiful extent of property.

If you get food to go in the Quarter, the Riverfront Park is a great place to eat and take in the barges and cruise ships on the river. The pandhandlers can be a bit of a bother and run some scam betting they can tell you where you got your shoes (best not to engage them) but other than...

title: Voodoo Authentica, New Orleans
review_list:
Great little place was very happy with the reading got me some oils very pleasant environment saw a tour there but I was just there for the reading and oils .

Went on a Voodoo Walking tour to learn more about its history and this was one of the recommended places to step into afterwards.
The staff is friendly and helpful. You can see someone who reads cards - but you will need to make an appointment.

This shop really is an authentic voodoo shop. Even if you don't intend to buy voodoo supplies it has information cards everywhere about the meanings of different items. It was very interesting!
Must see place in the French Quarter!

They were helpful and the shop is chock full of anything from stones to books to candles to statues! It's awesome! They also make custom gris gris for people. So sweet!

There was a lot to look at in here and a lot that confused me. They had some of the normal kitchy stuff you can get at every shop in NOLA but they also had some genuine things you could buy. We walked out empty-handed but looked around for like 15 minutes. It's a tiny shop so it's worth taking...

After taking a Voodoo tour through Free Tours by Foot, which I highly recommend, we were led here to check out the shop. More  



Cool spot to pop in. It's a bit crowded and overpriced, however I still splurged on a cat dio de los muertos trinket for $25.

More  



Recommended by 2 different tour guides, this shop had alters for offerings and had a great vibe, no commercial "voodoo" stuff, just authentic items and setup.

there are many voodoo shops, this was a nice one, not as many options as some others. But the staff was friendly and informative

title: Old St. Patrick's Church, New Orleans
address: 724 Camp St., At Girod, New Orleans, LA
review_list:
This is a beautiful old church that has been well cared for. Easy walk to it from the convention center area.
Check out my pictures and throw me a thumbs up please.

St Patrick's Church is the oldest parish church outside of the French Quarter. It is absolutely stunning and worth a visit.

Attended mass and did a photo tour at separate time. Stunning. Very moving for mass. Pastor gives a good sermon

Attended Mass here in December and was just amazed at how beautiful this church is. Build in the early 19th Century, it was built about a generation after the Louisiana Purchase, and a generation before the Civil War, so these pews have seen good times and very bad times. There is a lot to take in architecturally that is hard...


More  



Loved the history in this church. The murals were beautiful, the floors, that are marble have areas that are worn from years of use.

A beautiful church, hidden away in New Orleans.
I had the wonderful opportunity to attend a Latin Rite Mass here one Sunday, The Mass was wonderful, the chant was beyond compare, and the church is STUNNING.
Even if you are not Catholic, the architecture and paintings are a wonder to behold.
Truly a treasure.

Old St. Patrick's was a beautiful surprise on an early October Sunday morning. The church is beautiful inside and the choir and music only added to the experience . The entire mass was said and sung in Latin, something we had not experienced for many years. It was not only a throwback in time for us but an uplifting delight...


More  



The building is a beautiful place with ancient artifacts. Definitely worth seeing, especially if you love church architecture.

Even if you are an atheist you need to see the stained glass windows in this church. They are the best in New Orleans. Go there when it is open and celebrate the colors and glass art work. You will be glad you did. Stay to look at the Irish Channel.

Very interesting church, fantastic stained glass and tranquility all along, a must visit church. It is situated in a main square, so one can easily include in his itinerary.

title: Louisiana Children's Museum, New Orleans
review_list:
The Children's Museum is a great place for kids, with lots of hands on activities. It's activities range from simple machines, to art and architecture with areas for exercise and reading and lots more. On a rainy day this place is a wonderful option.

This is a great rainy day or hot day, indoor activity. Very walkable location just outside the French Quarter. Two floors filled with activities with a separate toddler area. Good for kids 10 and younger. Something I had not seen before was the area with speed measurements of thrown baseballs and footballs plus the air hockey table to teach angles.

In town visiting my grandson (and his folks, of course) and wanted to find something different to do. They live in the Warehouse district so the location was perfect. I took my chances and purchased tickets to check it out. He's only 13 months old but they told me, when I arrived, that there's an area upstairs for the little...


More  



It's great for kids and as a children's museum that should be the goal. There are two floors of fun, interactive exhibits, with some tied to the area while others would work anywhere (like the mini grocery store). It's the kind of place where after a few hours you have to coax your kids into leaving, so it will certainly...


More  



This museum prizes activities that foster children's creativity and spirit of adventure. We loved all of the settings that mimicked real life, such as a working grocery store, diner and cafe, and construction site. Our little one was thrilled. We will be sure to return!

Louisiana Children's Museum participates in the ASTC Travel Passport program, making it perfect for out-of-town tourists with kids. Lots of great hands-on exhibits. My kids loved it.

Our four year old had a good time. Similar to other musuems we have visited designed for kids, however it did have a strong local feel. She particularly enjoyed the mock grocery story and restaurant areas.

Overall, a good experience for our seven-year-old and three-year-old. There is one place where you can jump and dance in front of light, which will make psychedlic shadows. Another place takes strobe light shadow photos. Some places are a little run down and the place could use a good cleaning/updating. That said, the kids definitely will find quite a bit...


More  



The museum is very education and hands on. Many areas to meet all ages of children. Parents have fun also.

My son loved this place. It is one of the few children's museums which has something truly for all ages.

title: Lafayette No. 1, New Orleans
review_list:
I have been coming to New Orleans for YEARS and was appalled to find out that you now have to pay $25 to go through this cemetery -- which had previously been free since its inception. I will not be returning.

Our family enjoyed walking through here for 15 minutes and looking at the different graves. There are some uniquely inscribed graves to enjoy and it's free.

Beautiful and so interesting! Parked on a side street and walking around the ceremony. The age is remarkable on the crips and how whole families are buried together.

This is a lovely and historic cemetery in the Garden District. Definitely register for a tour either with Free Tours by Foot or the Save our Cemetery foundation. Well worth your time!

We got a cab from the french quarter to this cemetery rather than find a tour or anything. It was great and located in a really beautiful neighbourhood in the garden district. Be sure to walk around after and check out all of the interesting houses.
The cemetery itself was great. I enjoyed walking around at my own leisure rather...

We arranged our tour through Save our Cemeteries, and were very pleased. The guide loves his work and introduced us to things we didn't know we didn't know, like all the different types of tombs. Not much shade for escape from sun and heat, but it only took about 1 hour.

We took the tour from the bus and this was a beautiful cemetery. We did not go alone because most reviews warn against doing that.

A great place to do a self guided tour. There are plenty of free tour guides available online that you can follow along on your phone if you're interested in some of the history, or you can just move from grave to grave and let the headstones and tombs do the talking. Don't miss it.

It truly is a beautiful piece of history but is falling apart and needs some extra love. We did not have a tour through the cemetery but it was a stop during our bike tour where we were able to get out and walk around. Beautiful marble and stone plots everywhere.

We love visiting old cemeteries, and I'm so glad we stopped at this one. As we entered, they were just starting a tour. I can't remember the name of the woman holding the tour, but it was only $5. She explained the different methods of burial. We found it very interesting. So happy we got lucky when a tour was...


More

title: Smoothie King Center, New Orleans
address: 1501 Dave Dixon Drive, New Orleans, LA 70113

Saw the Lakers vs. Pelicans game here. Was a great experience that my boyfriend will never forget. Was very easy to get there with an Uber. Security is good as well.

This was a great venue. The sound, the atmosphere, the workers... All above expected. I'd love to attend another event or show here.

I have been to Smoothie King several times for concerts. This was my first basketball game and I had great seats. The food is typically good with a New Orleans flare. Overall it is well kept and clean. Great venue for sports and conerts

I've been to my share of stadiums after years of being a sports reporter in the Midwest and the Smoothie King Center compares favorably to many of the venues in which I've worked. I had never been to an NBA Stadium and this being my first it was great. I would recommend seeing a game here when you are in town.

We went there for the trans Siberian orchestra. Place was very clean not a bad seat in the house and the concert was awesome. Close parking and convenient restrooms and clean restrooms. Drinks were a little expensive but not too bad and expected. Going back in March for another concert and would love to see a basketball game in there.

Attended WWE Monday Night RAW here. Have to say this is one of the better arenas I have visited. Was a decent size, not too big nor small. The seats were very comfortable. Seems like a great place. We've been here several times for concerts & sporting events. Concession prices are what you'd expect from an arena. $8-$10 for beers. I attended a concert here with friends. It was a nice big facility. I would definitely return for another event here at this location.

title: St. Louis Cemetery No. 3, New Orleans
review_list:
this was part of a city tour we took - they bury their dead above ground and the monuments are worth seeing too - watch out for times that the gates are closed

If you visit New Orleans, one of its unique features is the architecture of its cemeteries. This one, about a mile from the French Quarter and close to City Park and the Art Museum, is considered one of the best examples.
The competition of sorts are St. Louis No. 1 (practically next to the quarter, but has limited times and...


More  



This was a stop on our city tour. It was very interesting to learn how the people of New Orleans bury their dead. Lots of history here. I would recommend a cemetery tour to everyone who visits New Orleans.

This isn't the most famous one in NOLA (St. Louis cemetery #1 is where you'll find voodoo queen Marie Laveau's crypt, and the pyramid tomb actor Nicholas Cage had built), but it's a good example of the typical crypt above-ground cemeteries there. You can also go in on your own (St. Lous cemetery #1 you need to be with a...


More  



Interesting to see how dead people must be kept in New Orleans.
Good information from a good guide.
Great monuments and crypts

It does get very hot during the tour so going early in the day or when it is overcast is recommended. There are almost to many tours going through at once and the few famous tombs can be hard to view with the crowds.

Great visit and a tour guide is very helpful. Very interesting history of how a cemetery works in NOLA. Processing of the crypt to hold multiple family members is very cool. Must see! Do this as part of a guided city tour.

This is a stunning and peaceful cemetery and the above-ground crypts and monuments are beautiful and very well maintained. I enjoy walking through this serene resting place during my annual visits to NO and have found that some of my most memorable photos have been taken here.

If you want to see a New Orleans cemetery and you're in or near the French Quarter, this is the place I'd go. This is an interesting place to visit away from the hustle & bustle of the French Quarter. We took a guided tour of the cemetery, which included stories about famous New Orleans families and the history of the graves and tombs.

title: New Orleans Historic Voodoo Museum, New Orleans
address: 724 Dumaine St., At Bourbon, New Orleans, LA 70116

A great little museum packed with artifacts and alters. Lots to see. The very nice lady who did the introduction was friendly, funny, and informative. The gift shop is nice as well. Totally worth the $5 admission fee.

title: Algiers Point, New Orleans

title: Lafayette Square, New Orleans
address: St. Charles Avenue, New Orleans, LA
review_list:

~Christy

This is a nice green space in the middle of town. I was a bit disappointed there was not a statue of Lafayette, but Ben Franklin's statue was nice! He was a cool dude!

We were totally entertained during Blues & Bar BQ fest in the Sq. Nice area and restaurants to choose from, face in the direction the statues face and go left.

Visited this park for the 2015 Crescent City Blues and BBQ Festival. Park was able to accommodate a lot of people walking and laying around. Good amount of shade. Steps on statue made for great seating.

Walking from uptown to bourbon st you will pass right through it. A beautiful green belt among the high rises. Nice monument but full of homeless at night.

Sad to hear this local haunt is closing. Lots of fun inside & loaded with history of New Orleans. Beautiful room upstairs available for parties & soirees.

The perfect short cut from the French Quarter to Elizabeth's Restaurant in Bywater! Super clean, excellent metalwork and security cameras everywhere. Very nice!

Be sure to take a break and enjoy some quiet time from the City. Stroll along the river and enjoy the peace and beauty.

When we visited Crescent Park on a sunny Saturday afternoon in November, there were very few others enjoying this new and beautifully landscaped addition to NOLA's attractions. It is so peaceful, so invigorating.. Abandoned Riverfront warehouses have been opened up and cleaned up. We entered Crescent Park near the French Market over an elevated pedestrian walkway. The idea of reclaiming the waterfront for recreational purposes is a good one. This park is 2 miles long / and accessible from a few different spots where you can cross over the levies and the railroad tracks.

I used this park to jog along the Mississippi River while staying at a B&B in the Marigny. Such a beautiful space. Has the most amazing view of the city and river I have found after living here for 26yrs. This park was very convenient to run along the Mississippi river passed the Wolfenburg park. Make sure to clinm those stairs as the park sits on the other side of the railway, just after a factory building that separate wolfenberg and crescent parks.

title: New Orleans Botanical Gardens, New Orleans
review_list:

Outdoors, the ancient live oak trees evoke photos of the south with century old limbs that...

The gardens are within walking distance of the art museum and the sculpture garden. They are a nice diversion if it is not too hot. It does not take long to go through and it is pleasant enough. I would not go out of my way unless you are seriously into plants.

I have to say it was one of the most beautiful gardens I have been to. I especially loved the train garden.

On a nice January day it was a treat for Bostonians to see roses in bloom in this modest but lovely botanical garden. You need to prowl about to find the many varied settings, some of which are top flight. Especially good is the relatively new Enrique Alférez Sculpture Garden. Alferez's output over a very long career is nicely set...

I am inspired by man's fusion of nature and art. This is the perfect pallet for such fusion.

It was a nice garden, but I guess that the time of year we went things looked like they hadn't been looked after like you'd expect in a Botanical Garden. Things were over grown and looked sloppy. Also the green house where the kept the succulents was locked, so I couldn't look in there.

The gardens are lovely but certainly not the prettiest I’ve ever seen. They are doing a lot of construction in the back so I can only assume they are improving it. It took us about 1 hr to see it all. Small entrance fee required.

I spend about an hour there just rambling through the different paths and gardens. I was so mesmerized by the Lilly pad pond, that I probably took 50 pictures of it. Also, there was a small hummingbird, butterfly garden that I walked through. The conservatory was warm, lush green with tropical plants and plants from the dinosaur age.

For a large city, this botanical gardens was disappointing. Other such gardens I have visited were much better. Also, at this time there is a lot of construction ongoing in the gardens area and this subtracts from the overall gardens.

title: Chartres Street, New Orleans
review_list:
This a nice street to pick out little shops to visit. There are a ton of areas to shop, but this is another nice place to check out.

I'm rating this second to Royal and ahead of Bourbon for a good French Quarter experience. The crowds are more fluid than Royal (many are just heading to and from Jackson Square) and less rowdy than Bourbon. The history is here, too. Many cool buildings, interesting shops and popular restaurants.

To me every street in the quarter has great places to visit and see. Chartres has some wonderful shops... and there is always something to catch your eye in the windows.. And Food?? well its New Orleans there is great food on just about every corner.. Ask a local for their fav spot

After walking around the quarter we realized it was getting late, went into Snug Harbor for a burger, found the kitchen closed. Now what?... thank you Pedi-cab guys, especially Mag. She toted us to Chartres st. Had to drop off at the corner due to construction. She told us about this place called DAISY DUKES. Food finally. .. and it...

Some good restaurants and shops. More low key than Bourbon and a whole lot less ghetto than Decatur. Make sure to visit the Chartes House for some great bbq shrimp! In October 2015, the entire 100 block (closest to canal) is being torn up and repaired. The road and some of the sidewalk is closed.

Some of the best restaurants and bars are on Chartres street. Great place to get off bourbon have some good drinks at the Chartres house then take in some of the book shops on the street.

Like most of the New Orleans this street has a great vibe and some great bars with live music. We were there for Mardi Gras and it was nice to escape from Bourbon Street. This still had all the buzz, but more upmarket than Bourbon Street.

Love to go to New Orleans. So many museums to see and places to eat. weekdays are not quite so crowded during the main part of the day.

A wonderful New Orleans street worth checking out. Has some cool shops and restaurants to see. Of course the architecture is very neat and varied. Who knew? A French impressionist master in the new world! We were amazed to learn that Eduard Degas's mother was from a Creole family and that he spent time in New Orleans visiting his cousins. title: Lower 9th Ward, New Orleans
review_list:
Really grabs your heart to see what the people went through. Some reconstruction but Mississippi river still 17' above the city of New Orleans.

Did a little drive around the 9th Ward on a Sunday morning to experience what it was like in the Katrina ravaged neighborhood. Many people still live there so we didn't want to be too voyeuristic ... but the abandoned homes & empty lots give you the sad feeling of what those who live there had to go through.

Visited numerous areas and it is clear the community still has a way to go. The new high school about to open should help with the community building.

To fully understand the devastation of katrina you must visit the Lower 9th Ward DURING THE DAY and if you are lucky enough - to have a conversation with one of the few residents about the real impacts of the storm 10 years later - the media lies and the government has failed - learn for yourself firsthand and see...

I first visited the Lower 9th in February, 2006, just a few months after Katrina. The place was a total disaster. Limited electricity, utilities, not stores, service stations, hospitals, schools, stop lights, or anything else resembling a major neighborhood. FEMA trailers were everywhere. Since then I've returned four times and each time there is visible improvement but large areas remain...

I visited the area on a Sunday morning circa 10am in a hire car with my family. I felt it was safe enough and drove around for nearly 30 minutes without incident or seeing anything threatening. Much of the devastated area has been cleared to vacant lots on the north side, however there are still many derelict abandoned brick houses...


More  



It is nice the see the neighborhood is coming back, but after ten tears I think a little too slowly.

Very impressive to see, but keep in mind that this neighborhood can be...

I wanted to experience the 9th ward post -katrina , my experience was hope and vitality. It was so chilling to,read about the catastrophe. But was so wonderful to experience the come back .

If you have an hour, a car and a New Orleans street map or gps you should visit the Lower Ninth Ward. Twenty feet of water devastated this area destroying approx. 5000 homes. My Favorite area of NOLA. Artsy, interesting, cool shops and restaurants. Not touristy but definitely must see area. Within walking distance of French Quarter.

By far the best place to stay, drink, and eat in New Orleans. Full of locals, by far the best restaurants in the city and the much quieter side of New Orleans. Not to be missed.

It's an up and coming area full of bars, hotels and shops and more opens up all the time. It's close enough to the craziness of Bourbon, but far enough away for quiet love the converted warehouse hotels.

We spent some serious time here bouncing from museums to art galleries and breaking off in the area Bistros for a bit of an energy boost against walking in the southern heat. Loved the area and all the historic squares. Highly recommend for some New Orleans history and local creativity.

Well done! Love the place and eager to visit the Library tomorrow.

This was an excellent morning spent watching the glass blowers in action. prier to that we were sat down to watch a video of the art of glass blowing by the owner Mark Rosenbaum.

Stopped by the Rosetree Blown Glass studio and just loved my visit there. The owners are extremely friendly and willing to explain the process of how they make their beautiful art.
