title: Storyland, New Orleans
review_list:
This was a small but cheap bit of fun for the kids. This particular area had different play areas based off of children's books. Kids can walk and enjoy the scenery. They got to explore a rocket, see models of the three houses the pigs built, see the shoe that the old lady lived in, etc. It didn't take long...


More  



We road the street car out here and enjoyed the walk through the park. Storyland is only $4/person. It was a fun play area for kids probably 8 and younger. Things to climb on and a couple of slides. Tree covered walkways throughout the area. Small so it only takes an hour or less to see everything. It does have...


More  



The kids loved the fast dragon slide and enjoyed climbing around on the different story book features. It held their attention for an hour.

Storyland itself isn't very big and can be gone through in about 30 mins. I wouldn't make a special trip to see it. The trees are beautiful and there's plenty of shade. The walkways are uneven and the little houses look a bit in disrepair. There are two slides (one wasn't working when we were there.) My daughter had a...


More  



Visited with our 4 year old who seemed quite happy at Storyland. Parents and grandparents couldn't quite overlook the fact that the park is falling in disrepair. Building are crumbling and everything needed a good scraping and a new coat of paint (or 2). This is a 15 min attraction.

Young children love this place! You can spend hours here letting little children run and play all over the story land area.

The good: love the trees! Cute premise in a run down way. Friendly attendant who helped us. We were the only ones here on a Friday afternoon. I don't know if it's just deserted or bc of all the construction. The amusement park was closed and there were barricades up surrounding Storyland. There was also construction in the Botanical Gardens...


More  



Old live oaks form a complete canopy over the rides and attractions in this park. Mostly for children, but adults will enjoy it as well. The continents oldest carousel is located here and is the highlight of the visit. Sit with a snowball and watch the kids play while you enjoy the natural scenery and all the sites.

$4 a pop for the adults, 18 month old child free, two hours of squeals and giggles... Priceless!
Great way to let a sprout run around and tire them out!

My 4.5 year old son had a blast running from one nursery rhyme character to the next. There are cute slides for the kids to go on too. It is definitely more geared for the under 5 age group though.

title: Anatolian Silver, New Orleans
address: 1235 N. Peters St, French Market, New Orleans, LA 70116
review_list:
I always go to the French Market when I visit NOLA. I try not to make eye contact with the jewelry booth owners because once you do they latch on to you and try to bargain when your just looking, Its very uncomfortable. But not this booth. Anatolian Silver was so nice, so polite. Let me look around with no...


More  



Wandering through historic French market came to this clean stall with gorgeous very well priced jewellery - Stirling silver. I bought for myself and many gifts as the price, variety and quality was the best in the market and they all came in lovely little gift bag. The vendor Hasan wasn't rude or pushy and he gave us some really...


More  



This jewelry shop located in the Historic French Market beats all for quality jewelry @ competitive prices. The selection varies from the traditional fleur de lys, to the modern NOLA water meter & come in pendants as well as earrings. He also carries crosses, and traditional type gifts. The selection and price cannot be beat.

Excellent variety of silver items suitable as gifts for my friends and young family members. Fairly priced and nice quality. Worth seeking out!

If you love New Orleans and looking for that perfect, not over-stated piece of jewelry, please stop in to Anatolian Silver. Today I purchased 2 pendants that come with chains, 2 charms and a pair of earrings. Less than $100. Since this trip to NOLA is extended, I will be going back for Christmas gifts. Don't be fooled by the...


More  



The best place to buy great quality silver jewelry. I wear mine daily and always want to purchase here. Highly recommended above any other vendor and the best prices!

While visiting family in New Orleans, I stopped at Anatolian Silver. My brother shops here for gifts for us and the quality and beauty are unsurpassed. I got the most beautiful silver earrings for a really reasonable price. Mr. Cicek was so helpful and knowledgeable and it was a wonderful shopping experience.

I shopped around a bit in the French Market and found the prices here at Anatolian Silver to be the best, plus Mr. Cicek is very friendly and nice to talk to. Ask him to show you a picture of his cat! I bought several pieces of silver jewelry and am very happy with my purchases.

Very pretty designs with high quality semi-precious stones and low prices. Have been a repeat customer for over ten years and will continue to shop whenever we visit N.O.

Mr. Cicek and his wife were friendly & extremely knowledgeable about their jewelry. Super patient and not pushy, Mr. Cicek allowed me to enjoy my shopping experience. Thank you for the beautiful earrings (I brought 6 pairs :-) and great conversation!!!!

title: Voodoo Spiritual Temple, New Orleans
review_list:
Go to a Real Vodoun Mambo like Sallie Ann Glassman at La Salvation Botanica.Always research first! Sallie Ann is one of the few legit Mambos in the US that many people fly in to see.

Visit Priestess Miriam. She is a wonderful, kind soul. Learn about New Orleans Voodoo in a safe, non-scary setting based on spirit. Definitely a different experience, but a NOLA experience worth doing. Ask to tour the temple, for a donation. Interesting, different, and on point.

I stopped by here upon suggestion from a local as well as some good reviews online. I was looking for an authentic voodoo/ root religion experience after learning a lot about it locally. Going in expecting to meet someone to share some thoughts with - ask questions to, we were greeted by a woman (not the priestess) sitting in the...


More  



My friend and I went expecting to learn more about voodoo but we were greatly disappointed. The space is set up more like a shop and there is a shrine where you can put your offerings. However, the whole time we were there NONE of the people who worked there bothered to come out to say hi or ask if...


More  



The whole time I visited, I honestly didn't know how to feel. Nothing gave me the creeps about the place, but I did think it was odd that a place with that much "spiritual" presence was so visible and open for people to by trinkets from. Nevertheless, I bought some decent incense from there and left a coin behind.

Enjoyed our visit here very much. Priestess Miriam was a delight to talk with and enjoyed her tour the temple which was like the most interesting museum I have ever seen. The shop had a variety of reasonable priced trinkets. Enjoyed the visit here so much especially just having conversation with Miss Miriam.

As a not religious person the visit was a very interesting experience. We knocked on the door and priestess Miriam invited us to her places. We entered the shop and were not sure if that was all. We almost were on our way out when we figured out that you have to cross the shop and the temple is is...


More  



We dropped in and went on...... a very enlightening experience with our host.
Man is she spiritual!... in a VOODOO way that was very heart felt and conveyed throughout our many DEEP conversations.
You can tell the moment you go in she is the real deal.

Met her and visited the Temple with Altars to Spirits where she does her African Bonecasting readings. Adjoining Culture Center which had a retail store with great authentic African handcraft items at a very reasonable price for touristsd on a budget. This is a one of a kind in the world must visit.

Very accurate. My visit here was approximately 8 yrs ago, it still resonates.
I would like to visit again.

title: M.S. Rau Antiques, New Orleans
review_list:
What a place! Full of items that are not antiques just because they are old, but rather because they are the best items in their class. I was getting dizzy from all the Tiffany silver sets. I may not be able to afford much of it, but I was immensely impressed with their collections and staff expertise.
We went to...


More  



What an inventory, what a staff, what an experience! An hour wasn't enough, we were back a second day. I have a collectors' interest in some of the items shown - staff members were helpful, friendly and interested in my interests. No push - just the kind of people and store I hope to deal with again someday soon.
Visitors...


More  



One source says what seems to be an elegant "little" shop has over 30,000 sq ft in a warren of rooms that seem to go forever. This place is fascinating, enlightening, and free. And the staff are always courteous and welcoming, which is much appreciated by this sometimes footsore fan of history and things historical.
Want to see Admiral Lord...


More  



An article appeared on my news feed while in NOLA calling it one of the top 13 spooky things to do while visiting. There is a "hidden room" you can ask to see by tour. The room wasn't exactly spooky but the rare items left us in awe. They have some of the most beautiful items in their showroom as...


More  



Get off Bourbon Street and stroll down Royal Street with its wonderful shops. M.S. Rau's Antique shop is not to be missed. It's like walking through a history museum. The silver, china, jewelry, furniture, and many other items are gorgeous. The staff is friendly and helpful, even if it's obvious the customer is only browsing (which would be us). I've...


More  



We stopped in M.S. Rau Antiques while roaming Royal Street. It's deceptively small from the outside. Once inside there are many twists and turns. The merchandise for sale is of unbelievable quality and rarity. Gifts from the pope, large meteorites, an Enigma machine are just a few examples. The variety is astounding. The sales agents let you roam freely and...


More  



Walking into M.S. Rau Antiques, you'll feel like you've been transported back in time to different places and different cultures. The shop is a stunning array of artifacts from all over the world. Look closely in the cases and on all the shelves. You'll feel like you're in a museum of historic randomness. Really lovely place.

A wonderful place for collectors or to "window shop" if you aren't rich enough to be a collector. Some really beautiful and unusual items and the staff was very nice to us even though we were clearly "just browsing".

Lots of expensive things. But fun to go in and see. Always stop by just to look. Worth it. Jewelry is amazing. Don't pass up.

This is an internationally renown antique and art dealer. They currently have art by Renoir, Van Gogh, Monet, and Rockwell. The staff is very friendly and happy to answer any questions you have. If you have a group, they will do tours, time permitting.

title: Holocaust Memorial, New Orleans
address: Bienville Street & River Walk, New Orleans, LA
review_list:
Lovely memorial along the Mississippi River. The Slabs provide a different image from the designated vantage points marked around the memorial.

The Holocaust Memorial is a beautiful work of art. As you walk around the memorial -- which features a number of brightly painted vertical sheets -- images of a bright yellow Star of David and a Menorah appear. Beautifully done. Right on the waterfront. Simple, elegant, moving tribute to the victims of the Holocaust.

Beautiful and touching memorial along the river walk. It is a interesting looking piece of art that changes perspective as you walk past.

Went to Woldenberg Park several times to walk my dogs before actually going up to the monument to see exactly what it was. I knew it was colorful and in a good location but nothing more. What it turned out to be was a well thought out Holocaust Memorial, with a changing narrative depending on which direction it is view....


More  



I am sure many many people walk by this exhibit with out realizing what it even represents or the hours of thought and creativity that went into this piece of art. Reading the description of each phase is powerful. We were here the day of the historic marriage equality ammendment and reading that 11m people were killed for their differences,...


More  



Situated along the riverfront this memorial is very different, I had no idea until I read the plaque that it had anything to do with the holocaust... ...its different..

This is a simple memorial along the river that represents one of the most tragic events in human history. It is not a must see attraction but everyone should walk by it and remember the victims.

We decided to walk from our hotel to the French Quarter and came upon the Holocaust Memorial. It's a beautiful installation and like other reviewers have said read the plaque first then walk around it and watch it change. This was a very nice discovery for the beginning of our walk.

Very cool once you read the plaque that explains where and how to view the memorial. Read first, then walk around. Very cool.

As my wife and I were walking along the Riverwalk, we came upon the Holocaust Memorial. Our city tour guide explained the Jewish history of the city but did not mention a memorial. The colors used are eye catching. This is a great addition to the French Quarter.

title: Museum of Death, New Orleans
review_list:
This is not a museum of folklore or voodoo. This is a museum of history, particularly serial killers and death row inmates. If you get a chance, talk with the museum curator for personal stories. It's not a large museum, however, that's good because there is so much to read from prison letters to newspaper articles. There's also a number...


More  



We weren't really sure what to expect but this place is definitely interesting. Not for the faint of heart and involves a lot of reading of the articles and letters.
The owner was extremely friendly and helpful!

HA! I am a fan of the macabre and I must say I was impressed with this place. Very interesting! Worth stopping in. Not as gruesome as I had hoped but for the average person it's probably right on point. I loved the exhibits on serial killers and the antique mortuary items. Probably one of the best places in New...


More  



My granddaughter has been talking about going to the Museum of Death since before it opened last year. She was not disappointed with this visit. Lots of exhibits and weird stories. The owner, Scottie, was most gracious to me (who chose not to see the exhibits). While I sat in front waiting for her, it was so nice to see...


More  



I enjoy the darker things in life. The Museum of Death is definitely the right place to go. I thought I was ready but it was really disturbing seeing all the handwritten letters by killers.
The owner was extremely nice, but the place itself is quite disturbing.
Overall I would rate it a 9/10

Now i've been to a few weird wacky museums so had to try out this one. It contains artwork/letters from several serial killers and crime scene photos. The most disturbing was the video loop of macabre deaths playing in the theater. If you are even the slightest of faint of heart this is where your queasy is tested. The soundtrack...


More  



I hadn't heard of this place during my planning, but was happy to accidentally notice it on my google map as I was orienting myself one day. Super cool find! Impressive collection of all sorts of death-related stuff through the ages, ranging from crime scene and car accident photos to drawings and letters written by murderers. Don't go here if...


More  



Lots of interesting things to see and read. If you don't like gore there's still plenty of history to learn. Could spend all day there reading newspaper headlines, crime reports, interviews, letters from inmates, etc.

This museum if full of many different unique and morbid oddities that all revolve around death. *Not for cowards or prudes* You'll find treasures like shrunken heads, Jack Kevorkian artwork, letters from serial killers while in prison, photos of famous people post-mortem, old newsletters, and more! If you have a moment after your tour, you should talk to the guy...


More  



This place made me feel very uncomfortable, and I was not expecting it to. I love crime shows and stories about serial killers and such so I didn't expect to be so bothered by what I saw but I was wrong.
The museum itself was not bad. Some of the exhibits were interesting, and the owner was very, very nice....


More

title: The House of Dance and Feathers, New Orleans
review_list:
There is so much to see in this collection - infinitely detailed Mardi Gras Indian parade costumes, ossified wine bottles, collections of shoes from the Muses parade, photographs of different chiefs, elaborately feathered second-line umbrellas...and so much to learn from its host, the gracious Mr. Ronald Lewis, whose formidable knowledge of the neighborhood and its traditions bring the smallest element...


More  



Ronald Lewis, the founder and keeper of The House of Dance and Feathers is an incredible storyteller, activist, and artist who guides you through histories of New Orleans. From the devastation, injustice, and community action resulting from Hurricane Katrina to a colorful and thoughtful explanation of Mardi Gras Indians, everything we learned enthralled and inspired us. His collection is breathtaking...


More  



We were brought here on the excellent Lower 9th Rebirth bicycle tour run out of the Confederacy of Cruisers cycle shop.
Mr Lewis is a fascinating character with so much history and so many stories that he can totally captivate you for a long, long time. Yes the 'museum' is essentially an outbuilding in his yard piled high with artefacts...


More  



It's really difficult to put into words just how cool this place is. Not only can you learn about the culture of the Mardi Gras Indians and African American Social Clubs, but you get to learn the history of the Lower Ninth community pre and post Katrina. Ronald has story upon story and is willing to share each and everyone....


More  



Well it was a teeny bit hard to find and a little bit out of the way deep in the 9th ward. The proprietor was an interesting character who has collected every article in there or had donations from personal friends.
His knowledge of New Orleans, black culture and native American interactions with black history in Louisiana was incredible. The...


More  



When visiting New Orleans, take a break from the typical Bourbon street dining and drinking activities and enjoy some real cultural Louisiana history and stories from one of the most amazing people I have ever met. His stories will fascinate you. His memorabilia from Mardi Gras ( The Second Line) parades will amaze you and his pictures and real life...


More  



This is basically one man's tribute to the endangered culture of the Mardi Gras" Indians" from the 9th ward. He gathered up many relics after the storm and put them into a "museum" in his backyard, which he runs with his two adorable granddaughters. The owner, Mr. Lewis, is himself part of the Mardi Gras Indian tradition going back many...


More  



We were honored to be able to visit this national treasure of a museum in the backyard of Ronald Lewis. He has showcased the amazing heritage and culture of the Mardi Gras Indians through costumes, photos, books and more. Everything from parade throws, hand beaded costumes worn by the Indians to samples of the food and water provided to them...


More  



Ronald Lewis is the most engaging host and his collection of artifacts, as well as his stories and photos of his time with the Mardi Gras Indians is a fascinating piece of New Orleans history. There is no fee to enter, but donations are helpful!

I was so happy I took my family here. It is the most real experience you will have in NOLA. Mr. Lewis is an incredible wealth of knowledge of Mardi Gras and New Orleans history. Great artifacts you can touch and really experience. I highly recommend visiting. There is no fee but whatever donation you want to make.

title: New Orleans - Hop On, Hop Off Tour, New Orleans
review_list:
The published route was cut short, which didn't allow us to drive by the Super Dome. They also gave us a brochure for free play at Harrahs, but of course they didn't honor it. Be prepared for the nasty condition of the NOLA streets and a very rough ride.

The tour is about 2 hours, with optional walking tours as well. Ticket was good for 3 days. Great way to learn about city and get around. We enjoyed our tour guide and felt it was a good orientation to city. Would recommend for first time visitors

We took this tour and found some guides better than others but overall they all had the knowledge and information of the city to provide us a good background for what we wanted to explore in depth and others that what they said was enough. During construction and rush hour it is really difficult for them to come on time....


More  



I was a little skeptical about the price of this tour bus but after reading the reviews we decided to go ahead. (I also found coupons online) It's $39 per person but it's good for 3 days. (Watch the schedule during Mardi Gras. They don't run every day during that time) There are about 20 stop locations on their route...


More  



I purchased hop on/hop off tour bus while in Dublin and loved it. Since I was traveling solo I knew it would be helpful in getting around town as well as learning the unique things about the city. The tour guides were knowledgable and kind. The included walking tours in the Garden district and French Quarters were an added bonus.

We have tried these tours all around the world and this one was just what we expected. The first day we rode the entire circuit to get oriented... the guides were very personable and friendly.. AND knowledgeable. We had no problem finding seats the entire three days and it was an easy way to get around. Very well done and...


More  



Just booked a tour and waited over an hour for first bus to show. When buss finally arrived we only went 5 stops before taking a ten min. break and we were at start of route. History info was okay, but not worth the cost. Get a Jazzy Pass and explore.

we had the 3 day ticket and made good use of it, we parked our car and left it in the car park and used the bus to get around. Always get a lot of information on these buses and the guides on these were all great and local each one had different stories to tell of their childhood in...


More  



I used my ticket on a Thursday and Friday. On Thursday, the bus was mostly empty and Mary was our guide and Tasha and Tiffany (they switched) drove. The drivers did a good job and Mary had lots of historical and cultural information and her personal Katrina story was very moving. The second day, Friday, was much more crowded and...


More  



We were told to be at the bus stop at 4:30. You need to be on a bus at 4. The buses stop at 5 no matter what stop you are at.....confusing....good way to see the city.

title: City Sightseeing New Orleans, New Orleans
review_list:
Best way to see the city of New Orleans. Get a historical background of where you are while you get a sense of direction. Knowledgeable staff that will make you smile and laugh. You can get on and off at their designated stops and go explore and get guided tours. Best investment you'll make. Claudine and Jennifer were amazing.

My husband and I used the same company to see San Francisco a few years ago. Though the busses didn't seem to run quite "every 30 minutes," overall we were pleased with the purchase. We ended up only using the bus 2/3 days, but took advantage of some of the other discounts ($2 off per person at Mardi Gras World,...


More  



Never having been to New Orleans before we felt it would be good to do the tour, despite the cold and bitter wind, to get a feel for the place and find out what was where. Despite losing the bus tickets, and then finding them again, we enjoyed the trip and the hosts were very informative. We had a three...


More  



$39 for 3 days worth of transportation around New Orleans is a pretty good value. But don't pay for it if you're using it for much more. The tour guides range from disinterested to kind of energetic. Our first tour guide was texting on her phone for most of the tour and barely talked at all. We had another tour...


More  



Disappointed in tour. Not worth $39 for 3 days. Would of preferred to have 1 day pass for less. Unfortunately the weather was so cold we didn't want to get off the bus for fear of not being able to find a seat inside.

We received an informative tour in and around the city, which included the Super Dome, the French Quarter, the Garden District, Jackson Square and who of course could do a tour without pointing out one of Emeril's restaurants. However, if you're sitting on top of the bus, which one would think would have more vantage points, be careful. The hand-railing...


More  



When visiting New Orleans, I thought 3 days on a bus tour was way too much. Turns out it wasn't enough. There is lots to do. Jaime was the best tour guide.

Extremely well organised and knowledgeable tour guides. I would advise going at the beginning of your break as the guides will tell you the best restaurants to eat and places to revisit in this beautiful city

Pretty good overall. Jumped on n off 3 times in one day which was great because each guide added a different spin with their own interpretation of the sights.
Fare is good for 3 days and discounts for other stuff.
Good value

I recommend you take the Hop On Hop Off Bus tour on your first morning. It gives you an overview of the town along with its history. The guide was entertaining and informative, and the tour was extensive. The ticket is good for three days, so you can take the tour at your own pace.

title: Buzz Nola Bike Tours & Rentals, New Orleans
review_list:
A friend and I had a wonderful time enjoying the sights of New Orleans before the start of our cruise. Our guide was very pleasant and knowledgeable about the city and its history. We would highly recommend this tour to anyone. It was an easy, comfortable to see the best of all there is to see.

I recently went on my first trip to New Orleans and after some research I knew I wanted to see more of the city than just the French Quarter. The thing that appealed to me about a bike tour in New Orleans is that New Orleans is very flat and rideable for any skill level, and that the local drivers...


More  



If you have a short time in New Orleans and want to get away from crazy Bourbon Street do this!! We had Dario as our tour guide on the complete crescent tour. He was wonderful! Very knowledgeable about the city. Also, he did a great job at making sure we rode around safety. Was very nice to do something different...


More  



Seeing all the 5 star reviews (can anything be THAT good??) maybe my expectations were too high to give it 5 stars myself. But we had a great time, and looking back on our trip, this was one of the highlights. There was something a little too 'canned tour-guidy' about it to give 5 stars, but if you like cycling-...


More  



Took a trip to New Orleans with my company - the five of us had a wonderful experience with Buzz Nola! Chris was a pleasure to deal with, and Scott was a wonderful tour guide!

I had booked the Complete Cresent Tour and this was the first thing I had booked for my one week stay in Nola, and It sure was the best to start with. Get a ride with comfortable bikes in a slow pace and get the hang of the city in a neat way. By far better than any busride. We...


More  



We had Dario as our tour guide. Very personable and very savvy individual. He gave us an excellent insight to New Orleans. This tour shows you the beauty and history of the city. I learned so many new things that I was not aware off from this historical place. I will bring my family back to NOLA and do this...


More  



Would do it again! Nice equipment, thorough pre-instructions and easy to stay with group. The guide (Lindsay) was pleasant, fun, knowledgeable and helpful and communication was clear. Great way to see the area. Baskets on the front of the bikes can hold jackets etc. We rented bikes after to check out the garden district, it was fun. Bikes for day...


More  



First class bike tours led by experienced guides, we thought about just renting bikes and doing our own but the personality and attention of these tours made it an exceptional experience. Get the feel for different neighborhoods, get some local history and lore, and get some restaurant recommendations from these fabulous people.

We took the Garden Combo tour one day and loved exploring the city by bike so much we returned the next day to rent bikes and explore on our own. We learned a lot, got the lay of the land, and benefitted from local advice. Thanks BuzzNOLA!

title: The American Bicycle Rental Company, New Orleans
review_list:
I was in New Orleans for a conference and had a free afternoon to explore and I figured I could see the city quicker on a bike. I found American Bicycle Rental Co. on a rival website (they also have a fantastic mobile app that rhymes with 'help') and saw they had some good reviews and figured I give them...


More  



I called American Bicycle at the last moment on a Sunday to rent bikes for my husband and myself The bikes were great and the staff was extremely friendly and helpful. They were also flexible about the time when we needed to return the bikes . We enjoyed a great ride to lake pontrachain and back . It made for...


More  



Rente dbicycles here and was very happy. The bikes are in great mechanical condition. Ride excellent too. they give you a lock and chain to lock up when stopping. You are given amap of places to go and see as well as a road map to steer you in the right direction. Not expensive and staff was very helpful and...


More  



Had a blast on the bike for an hour! Great price, they even trust you to drop off the bike after hours. Friendly too. Bike was great! Go there!

Definitely recommend. Son and I rented bikes for the day. Extremely helpful and friendly. I intend to use them again

This simple bike rental does it all perfect. Easy policy, nicely maintained bikes, custom map with great recommendations and excellent customer service...
If I may gush with pleasure for a moment, the shops GM went above and beyond. There was a major rainstorm, I was rushing to catch an early morning flight and the guy showed up with a poncho...


More  



Rented bikes for 8 hours and went 25 miles all around NOLA on a self guided adventure. Bikes were great and they held up even over all of the cities bumps and potholes! Guys were great in explaining the places to hit. Map was great too. Easy return process even after hours. Overall a great experience.

Ryan was so friendly and nice to meet! 4 of us (all adults) rented bikes for 4 hours. The shop was about to close, but he still took the time to explain everything in great detail, go over the map, give us tips, recommend great local places to try and answer all our questions! He is very knowledgeable of places...


More  



We enjoyed the staff, the price was more than fair, the bikes were in great shape and their system for returning after hours works really well. Their commitment to high-quality American-made parts is admirable also.

The American Bicycle Rental Company is Great. Bikes that all parts work. The seat is big and easy to sit on. A bike map that is the best in the FQ. I have rented four times already.

title: A Bicycle Named Desire, New Orleans
review_list:
We couldn't have had a better experience than what we had with Bicycle Named Desire. They made everything easy. We completed our reservations over email and two gorgeous, well-maintained cruisers were waiting for us when we arrived at the shop the next morning. (We rented for the weekend and in that time I received no less than half-dozen compliments on...


More  



This is a great resource for rental cruisers. Their store is not just about bikes, but also has a nice collection of local art and guidebooks - a good place to do some gift shopping! The staff are helpful and VERY knowledgeable about the city. They took time to answer all of our questions, and showed us some really good...


More  



5 family members took bikes out for an afternoon. The bikes were very comfortable and in excellent condition. Staff very pleasant and helpful. Took the off-road Greenway route to the City Park and stopped for coffee and beignets before taking the cycle route back down Elysian Fields.

Renting bikes from A Bicycle Named Desire made exploring New Orleans outside of the French Quarter 200x easier and more enjoyable. These lovely folks set my honey and me up with comfy rides and, even better, gave us excellent restaurant recs, route advice and even some ideas for New Years Eve. They made our trip!

We rented bikes....really the only way to experience New Orleans. The staff is friendly and easy to reach. The bikes are well cared for and comfortable. I highly recommend this company for your bike rental. I will be using them again, next time I am in town!!

Trisha was great! Made some excellent recommendations for restaurants and places to go. Loved the "Confederacy of Dunces" references, since all 4 of us had read and loved the book. Some of the bikes had minor issues with seat slipping.

We went on a bike tour of some of the neighborhoods in New Orleans on the Friday after Thanksgiving. There were 7 of us on the tour. Cassady was informative, funny, and a terrific guide for all of us. We ranged in age from 21 to 58 and the ride was very doable without being in great "bike" shape. We...

The bikes were comfortable and cute. The shop has interesting items for sale by local artists. You can rent the bikes for several days so that you can really get a chance to see the city.

When I asked her to see specific statues at one of the cemeteries, she went out of her way to show me a couple. We did the Garden District and hope to do another walking tour with her next...


More  



Great tour. Group was small so you could interact with our guide, Christine, and move nimbly. I felt like Christine was respectful of people's homes and graves, where other tours were not.
Great way to get out and get an overview of that district and see some beautiful homes.

We toured on 1/5/16 with Christine. She has so much history of NOLA and made the tour incredible. We booked because Two Chicks offers small personal tours and that's what we got! Not only did Christine give an excellent tour, she made sure to give us other information on restaurants, etc. so our NOLA experience would be the best!

We had a great tour guide who was personal and effective in delivering the stories behind the mansions. Highly recommend.

Two friends and I were in NOLA for New Years, and we decided Two Chicks would be a good way to explore the city. Great 10 am start time for our tour meeting in front of a fantastic restaurant where I had the best coconut cream donut prior to the walk. I'm a local and I love this place! If you want to hear some good blues and experience some good New Orleans style music, then be sure to stop in at the Funky Pirate! With Big Al on the mike and a Hand Grenade in my hand, life is mighty good! Check it out y'all! Trust me, you'll have a...


More  



Had a blast
The live music was terrific. The decor and atmosphere was fun. Best on of the 3 bars owned by this company.

Good blues music, friendly staff and chatty fellow patrons- what more could you ask for!
When so much of Bourbon is filled with heavily intoxicated belligerent young people people, the Funky Pirate was very much our kind of place for some good music with like minded friendly people

One of the few bars on Bourbon St that offer blues/jazz music. If nothing else, stop by for a set and have a beer and relax to some great tunes! Seek it out, its worth it!

review_list:
I thoroughly enjoyed my dinner at the House of Blues. The voodoo shrimp was delicious. Also, the manager, Leon was very nice.

title: Prytania Theatre, New Orleans
review_list:
The Prytania Theatre is one of a kind. A single screen movie house set in the upper Garden District! Just Spectacular! Mr. Brunet hosts the Classic Movie Series (from Gone with the Wind to Breakfast at TIffany's) his stories of working in the theatre are the best! There is late night showings for the 'hip' crowd. The Prytania shows the...


More  



I've been lucky in my life to travel the US and live in nice places, but few places have charmed me a much as my two visits to the Prytania for a classic movie (shown Wednesday & Sunday mornings). At 91, Mr. Brunet still warmly greets movie goers at the door, then shares a few anecdotes about the film. After...


More  



Friendly staff, very comfy seats, nice snack bar, first-run films as well as vintage film nights. A great find in New Orleans!

I love this place so much. Single screen with great quality picture and sound. They have great concessions, and it's simply one of the most beautiful theaters I have ever been in.

The Prytania is an unspoiled theater offering some of New Orleans' most interesting movie selections.
Tucked away on an uptown street near the campuses of Loyola and Tulane, the Prytania does not offer the most high-tech moviegoing experience, but it is a friendly place, not owned by a chain and seemingly programmed by people who really appreciate a good movie....


More  



The Prytania existed when I was a kid. Throughout the years of massive blockbusters requiring screens the size of battleships, sound systems with enough power to deafen neighbors, and IMAX 3D everything, Prytania has held its own. The theater has a loyal following. They will periodically host older movies, themes, and fun events to generate revenue which you rarely see...


More  



This is the last of the original Movie Theaters that is still being used for movies. Center of the New Orleans Film Festival.

I went out to the Prytania on the St. Charles Ave. street car. The theater is well maintained, has a great concession stand, good prices, and a really excellent viewing experience. The staff was friendly and welcoming. My only regret is that i won't be here long enough to see some of the excellent upcoming festivals.

Shows film fests, current films, some of the Sundance variety, some as popular as the outlying 20-screen variety. Great owner who often shows up. People see neighbors all the time. Or come with them!

Step back in time to a one screen experience. This place has a great history and shows vintage and art films as well as current.

title: Carousel Gardens, New Orleans

Our young child had a great time at that park. Lots to do for a 4 year old and no line up. In a couple of hours, we could do all the rides and even repeat some. My family loves to go to this amusement park! There are rides and fun here for all ages! We've been attending this park for many years.

We just finished mini golf across the parking lot and the kids (11 and 14) wanted to ride a few of the rides. I highly recommend you buy the full day pass if you are a tourist. It is good from 10:00-10:00 and my 5.5 yr old loved all the classic rides. I think it may be a bit too young for children over 8 yrs but perfect for the 4-7 year-old range. We had a great time and loved that we could...

We took about 15 teenage girls on Saturday evening for a couple of hours. They had a blast. The park wasn't crowded, and the girls were able to have a fun time together without getting lost in a crowd. We wished we had gone a little earlier in order to see the sculpture garden, art museum, and ride the train!

The continent's oldest carousel is located here in a small amusement area of the fabulous City Park. Filled with huge live oaks, rides, and of course, the magnificent Carousel! Tour this after you stroll through the Botanical gardens just next door and have a great time

The carousel is beautiful and my child really loves it. The train ride is also a great way to see a bit of the park. My kid is too short to ride most of the other rides which mostly seem to be fair carnival type rides but we have fun when we go

What a sweet little amusement park. Our 9 year old twins loved it. The rides are great, very small area that is easy to walk around, a good time was had by all of us. Big thumbs up for families with young kids!

This little gem is tucked away in a city park in New Orleans. It is perfect for families with young children. There is a nice mix of adult rides and children's rides. review_list:
This gilded statue of Joan of Arc, which was a gift from the French government, sits in the tiny Place de France park, right next to the French Markey area on Decatur.
Joan was the Maid of Orleans, so what better city for her statue.
Say Hi when you walk by or rest on one of the benches.
Very attractive...


More  



No trip to the City is complete without a visit to see the Lady. It's in a nice spot off the corner of Jackson Square, by the French Market.

It's a gilded statue...of Joan of Arc...It's a nice statue, as statues go, but I really don't think there's much more to be said about it than that. If you are a big fan of statues, you'll definitely like this one. If you are a big fan of gold statues, you'll love it.

Jean d' Arc is the maid of Orleans and this statue was gift to the city of NOLA. It was originally outside of the River gate at the foot of Canal Street. However, it was decided that since the casino was there the statue had to go. So they found this less prominent spot for the Maid Of Orleans. It...

Conveniently located near the French Market, we spotted the beautiful statue easily. It's a pretty statue and typically doesn't have people surrounding it.

when we pass this statue my wife always yells joanny on a pony -- this poor statue has been moved around the area that when we see it the wife has to yell out loud --- look for it is pretty golden statue and read the inscription too

We stumbled upon the statue whilst exploring the French Quarter. The statue is sited in a small grassed area next to the French Market and is definately worth a photo stop!

In a triangle of land dividing Decatur and N. Peters Streets stands this gilt statue of Jean D'Arc aboard her horse flanked by two old cannon.

This statue is absolutely gorgeous. I didnt even know it existed. We just stumbled upon it. It's a great place for a photo opp.

It's a beautiful statute to take pictures of. It's right next to the Mississippi river and the Frenchman market.

title: Our Lady Of Guadalupe Church, New Orleans
address: 411 N Rampart St, at Conti St, New Orleans, LA 70112
review_list:
I am not a believer, but I do believe in beautiful buildings, statues, and the unique religious soup which is New Orleans. In that vein, go here. Is it located in the most beautiful neighborhood? No. But it's fine and it's right on top of the French Quarter and right next to one of the famous graveyards that you should...

If you are Catholic stop and make a visit to the shrine of Saint Jude and the side alter dedicated to the our lady of Guadalupe. If you are not stop in to see the statuary. As you walk out of the church in your left hand side is the statue of Saint Expedite. Who is he? The story is...


More  



This church is one of the oldest in New Orleans and is home to St. Jude Shrine. It is a quaint church with beautiful stained glass and a come one come all spirit. Although not as ornate as some of the other Cathedrals in New Orleans; this one provides you with a great sense of community.

We had to search a bit outside the French Quarter to find this quaint little church. We were interested in visiting the shrine to St Jude, patron saint of lost causes. We also visited the gift shop which was a nice surprise. We purchased rosaries from Italy at reasonable prices along with medals and prayer cards. It is difficult to...


More  



This very modest church was so beautiful and so peaceful only. Few blocks of what is the craziest part of town. Came because of a promise and glad I did. Marveled at the history of the church. And what it does today. Wish I had had time to go to Sunday mass. A must see, Especially after I heard how...


More  



We visit there a few times a year. The church is beautiful and the grotto is a place where candles are lit, prayers are sent and answered. Fr. Tony Rigoli is an absolutely a wonderful, engaging, interactive priest. While there you feel that the Holy Spirit surrounds you and brings you peace. God Bless all who work there and visit...


More  



A peaceful, beautiful church. There is a lot of history in this building. The church welcomes all faiths to visit and worship together.

The church has a warm welcoming feeling. We did not attend mass but still there were others in the church. The church is beautiful and very well maintained. I have visited other churches and cathedrals and at times felt intimidated but not here, this feels so nice and friendly. I met Father Tony and he is a joy. Too bad...


More  



Make the Sunday 11:30 mass a must for your New Orleans visit. On the edge of the French Quarter, you'll feel welcomed the moment you walk in. Expect to hear some soulful, uplifting music and a great sermon from Fr. Tony. Get there a few minutes early to get a seat. If you're there on a weekend during football season,...


More  



Don't expect to sit still or lose yourself in quiet contemplation. title: Washington Artillery Park, New Orleans
review_list:
After stuffing yourself with beignets from nearby Cafe du Monde, this is a nice place to walk it off. Great views of the river and leads onto Moon Walk.

This is a small park across the street from Jackson Park. You have to climb some stairs to get to it, but It's a great vantage point to take pictures of Jackson Park, St. Louis Cathedral and surrounding buildings, and the Mississippi River.

A few feet from Café du Monde, this was a nice little historic find and a great place to have my coffee and rest. There's nothing much to it, but it definitely has nice views of the park across the street, of the waterways, and of the cathedral. I enjoyed just sitting there and enjoying the moment.

This is a small urban park located between the French Quarter and the levee. There are benches to rest on, and a civil war cannon is on display. From one side of the park you have the best elevated view of Jackson Square and all of the carriages lined up waiting for passengers. This view is the perfect photo op....


More  



A wonderful place to take a walk and see why the city is there. Of course you have the historical views with Jackson Square and the cannon. Very cool. But when you keep walking you come upon the mighty Mississippi and you are awe struck at its size and power. Really something to see. Bring your camera.

We walked through on our way from a day around the French Quarter headed back to the car. It's nice to wash off the grime and alcohol of the city with a stroll by the cathedral, the river, and some nice patches of grass to relax in (if it isn't 96 degrees in the shade.) Swing through, but don't go...


More  



As other reviewers have noted, Washington Artillery Park is a great location from which to photograph both the river and Jackson Square. If you want an absolutely wonderful souvenir of your New Orleans visit, have someone photograph you while you are standing at the railing on the Jackson Square side of the cannon. From one side you get great views of Jackson square and the other side the Mississippi river and stream boats. Take lots of pictures!!!

We discovered this park while looking for someplace to sit to enjoy our beignets. There are beautiful views of the river and Jackson Park. This is a great place to take pictures.

Washington Artillery Park is a small area with a cannon and some benches. The best part about it are the views it offers. On one side, there is a river view and you can watch the ships go in and out. On the other side, there's a great view of St. Paul's and the square around it. Great for photo...

This cemetery was so great for our whole group (adults, teens, and babies). Everyone enjoyed seeing the different tombs. It's definitely neat to see a different way of doing things from where we are from. It's sad, being at a cemetery, but it's a quiet relaxed vibe with some history.

It's very sad to see how the damp weather has decayed the mausoleums in St Louis #2, and there doesn't seem to be any upkeep.

title: Lower 9th Ward Living Museum, New Orleans
review_list:
Visited this museum during a recent visit to New Orleans. It was a transformational experience for me as I thought the perspective/voice of the residents were aptly depicted. This museum chronicles the history of the Lower Ninth Ward before it was decimated by Hurricane Katrina and after. The museum is modest in presentation (not a lot of bells and whistles)...


More  



This is a must see in New Orleans. If you have time take a trip to see this very strong monument to the suffering of the Lower Ninth Ward. Put away any preconceived notions of blame and take in a grass roots memorial.

This living museum shows how people live from day to day, It's not full of treasures, but shows a life well lived, even it is to an extent materially deprived. Take a look, it's worth it.

I arrived almost at closing time but the lady managing the place was very friendly & allowed me to come in & encouraged me to take my time. Place is small but is well organized to tell a story. It gives an intelligible understanding what these people went through. Time well spent, I will return on my next trip to...


More  



This is a tiny museum but don't let that fool you. We spent two hours mesmerized by the history, the personal stories and the policy/follow-through failures that led to the devastation of the Ninth Ward post Katrina. Go to this museum!!!!

The way the human beings living in this area have been treated by throughout history is a shameful disgrace. This museum really lays out the repeated, strategic disregard made by the local, state and federal governments for this community. It also gives a peek into the cultural heritage and some of the artists who've emerged from there. But the main...


More  



I visited New Orleans a few times and never made it to the 9th ward. This trip I was planning to do a tour but ran out of time, so I drove myself to 9th ward and found this museum. This was the best experience. I learned so much about the 9th ward. It was also about 2 blocks from...


More  



A vist to the Lower 9th Ward Living Museum is an absolute must for anyone travelling to New Orleans. It looks basic from the outset (set in a former home that, we were told, was submerged in 14ft of water during Hurricane Katrina) but the stories, images and video footage carefully gathered over the years make for a heart-renching and...


More  



The Lower 9th Ward Living Museum covers the history of the 9th Ward as well as current challenges of its residents.
This museum is free, simple, self directed, and small but it really got to me. I learned so much about how the people who lived there were treated and how they overcome.
Each room is colored a different bright...


More  



I remember hearing about the levee breach during Katrina but I didn't really connect it to anything. This museum gives you some background and stories told by the locals about how this area was impacted. It's a sad and maddening story that needs to be told! Go see for yourself.

title: Madame John's Legacy, New Orleans
review_list:
This is not a furnished period home, but one of the oldest in the city open to the public. Not only is this a great find for architecture buffs, but it houses a display of Arts and Crafts Newcomb pottery. This makes for an interesting half hour or so.

This is a great example of French colonial architecture that existed prior to a fire that destroyed much of the city during the eighteenth century. You can walk through the various rooms in the house and get a feel for how people lived in olden New Orleans times.

We really enjoyed this place as it showed the architecture of the 1700's in the French Quarter. If you are into firearms or rare coins or other things similiar this is the place to stop by and check out. Incredible collection

review_list:

Rodrigue Studio is home to the famous Blue Dog paintings. If anyone is to blame for the dozens of copycat ideas from individuals hoping to make millions by repainting a cat, dog, bird, fleur-des-lis, baby, red dog, or whatever, it is Rodrigue.
Over the years, the prices in this gallery have soared. I don't know if they have climbed on...

One of the many galleries on Royal street. Personally I don't see the attraction to the Blue Dog personally but worth going in to see his art.

I have never been so moved by art as I was when I wandered into the gallery with the Blue Dog. The art of George Rodrigue is amazing. The stories of each piece that are displayed in the gallery really adds to the impact of the art.

title: Haunted Houses, New Orleans
review_list:

title: Museum of Trade Finance and the Fed, New Orleans
address: 525 St. Charles Avenue, New Orleans, LA 70130
review_list:
A nice surprise. We didn't plan our visit we just popped in and were happy we did. A great rainy day activity or to get out of the heat!

Free shredded bags of currency is the highlight but maybe not worth going through security to enter this tiny little lobby with a few little information boards.

We stopped into this museum as we walked back from thew WWII Museum to our Hotel. We got a couple of bags of *money* as souvenirs and enjoyed a quick learning experience about The Fed. You have to go through Fed Security and Museum is one small room.

After going through security, you see an introductory video about New Orleans, a city with a mixture of cultures and where people came to trade. After a short visit through the exhibits, one can create an image of currency designed by themselves and a small bag of shredded...

Stumbled upon this small museum while walking by the Federal Reserve Building and seeing that it was free decided to venture in....Decidedly high security for entry, but yielding an informative, interesting and fun history of currency, banking and the Federal Reserve that necessitates but a fifteen minute tour.

This little museum is free and worth a stop. To see the whole thing only takes about five minutes and you get to take a bag of shredded currency as a souvenir. There is high security to get in that takes almost as long as seeing the whole museum.

We stopped by on our last day in town. Small musem but very informative. There is a station where you make your own money and they email it to you. It was a lot of fun. At the end there is a computer quiz to see what you leanred.

title: Arcadian Books, New Orleans
review_list:
This small space is literally a jumble of books. I went in a few feet and realized how disorganized and crowded the space is. I love books but not that much.

title: New Orleans Kayak Swamp Tours, New Orleans
review_list:
A great way to get into the swamp and out of the city. Tour guide was knowledgeable and friendly. Bring snacks and water. I felt very safe. Would highly recommend.

Bayous are a beautiful and magical place. Best seen by kayak. We learned about the fora and fauna and about edible and medicinal plants and so much about the people and eco system of the bayou.

The best part of our trip hands down! AJ was funny and engaging as well as very knowledgable about the area. Wish it was warmer but can't control the weather. :)

The kayak your at honey island was very fun. AJ our guide was incredibly friendly and knowledgable. Customer service seems to be their top priority and they do a great job of it. Beautiful sights while on the water.

What happened to Good Friends?

title: Hurricane Katrina Memorial, New Orleans
review_list:
This memorial is very tastefully done. It's beautiful and quiet. A wonderful place for reflection. I went to the 10th anniversary ceremony at this site and was kind of disappointed at all of the politicians and media that were present. I would have liked to see more local attendance.

I liked the extensive use of video media to tell the story of Hurricane Katrina, and the events leading up to it. The museum is well organised and interesting. Quite devastating. However, there was conflicting noise from the various videos that were playing at the same time.

A little hard to find but a must for tourists. It was a very sad reminder of all that was lost in hurricane Katrina and a good history lesson for the kids who don't know about or remember the tragedy.

Located directly across street from Morial Convention Center. Shows a small house in top of a tree - beautiful, low-key and poignant - also free. Strongly recommended.

I liked the displays and the testimonial video in the end. I wish it was more spead out. Some exhibits were too crowded to view.

Education about the events leading up to and following Hurricane Katrina. Unless you experienced it first hand, you really would have a hard time understanding the devastation that the people of New Orleans and the landscape endured. The Katrina Memorial, located next to St. Louis Cathedral in the square, is must see. It really helps you to understand the loss...

Memorial park inside the cemetery district in New Orleans. 1100 people died during the hurricane Katrina in August 2005. In this park, you can see the unmarked tombs of the hundreds of victimes who's body were never identified.

Dr. Bob's art gallery is a place that's like nowhere you've probably been before. It's extremely eclectic and somewhat bizarre, so very New Orleansean. Definitely worth a visit, the art is folksy and the attendants are interesting and fun to talk to as well.

My friend took me to check out the art; he goes every time he visits New Orleans. Huge selection of art in a variety of sizes and prices. I took two pieces home with me.

title: Poeyfarre Market, New Orleans
review_list:
This is definitely my favorite grocery store in town. Places like this are the reason why I love the city of New Orleans. I always make it a point to stop by when I'm in the warehouse district.

Poeyfarre is spectacular and really embodies New Orleans. You can often find the super-friendly brothers that own it working behind the counter and talking with the customers. They have great prepared food made on-site as well as a large selection of snacks, pastries, and drinks, including a good selection of wine and liquor.

We visted this store almost daily. Loved the coffee and the prepared meals. Great prices, and they sell alcohol.

Great neighborhood market with tons of great choices. One of the best iced coffees I've ever had-- mixed mine with some almond milk and simple syrup. Perfect treat to walk around with on a sunny day!

Very convenient walk from the Residence Inn. A little overpriced, but I would expect that from the area. Has a decent wine selection. I was glad to find out how close they were to my hotel. The puzzle art is amazing.

Poeyfarre is a great little market with healthy and tasty prepared meals, awesome coffee and helpful people. Their Veronica Blue salad with chicken is the best. I pick one up to take for lunch whenever I can. It's not cheap, but it's quality. You can get cheap anywhere.

Poeyfarre is my favorite place to get lunch in downtown NOLA! Amazingly friendly service, delicious sandwiches. Even better, their gourmet grocery store has things I just can't find at Rouse's. It is a pleasure to go in here and I love the fact that it is family owned. So convenient if you're in the CBD or Warehouse District. Highly recommend!

I come here for lunch at least once a week. It's great food and the owners are great. I would definitely recommend it for lunch and any last minute needs.

title: The Michalopoulos Gallery, New Orleans

Not to buy a print (or even a poster, for the budget conscious). The use of color and texture, the obvious love for the architecture and vibe of the city, I had to have it. It was a strain on the wallet, but I'll never regret my purchase.

The thing that most impressed me is that Mr. Michalopoulos has in him the same strange connection to the vibe of New Orleans that resides in...

Everyone should aspire to own art as amazing as this. If you do nothing else in New Orleans be sure to visit The Michalopoulos gallery. His paintings are windows into other dimensions.

my sister, Sherry and I drove all the way from Shreveport to Natchez to see Juanita at the "As You Like It" shop. We bought "Love Disarmed." Great black and white prints by known photographers in museum quality frames. Friendly service by a knowing staff.

Great space and location. Very interesting works which off the amateur photograph a different perspective and ideas. Great pieces.

I loved it, I dont have technical knowledge about photography but enjoyed every minute in this gallery, very beatiful and a great opportunity to appreciate fine photography. My brother is into professional photography and he had a blast!!

review_list:

I am willing to drive an hour to see a movie at this theater. No one under 17 is allowed to be in the theater. The food is great and just the right portion sizes. The ticket prices, food and parking add to the cost of seeing a movie here, but it is well worth it!

I love this theater and I love that they are showing live HD operas from the Met. The food was excellent and the service was wonderful. The seating was very comfortable. This was well worth the drive from Hattiesburg.

On a rainy afternoon in New Orleans, we decided to take in a movie. The Theatres at Canal Street were the only movie theatres I could find in the vicinity. We thought it would be nice to have overstuffed chairs and cocktail service during the show. The wait staff seems to forget that the guests are there to watch a...


More

title: The Theatre, New Orleans
address: 333 Canal Street, 3rd Floor, Shops at Canal Place, New Orleans, LA 70130
review_list:
Smaller screen than some of the other theaters, or least for a movie that has been out for a few week. My TV at home has better resolution but food served at your seat throughout the show. That includes snacks to meals plus beer, wine, cocktails or soft drinks

Canal Place used to be a great place to go to for a good independent movie. Now it is an overpriced theater with expensive food service. This place is a great example of the gentrification problem in New Orleans.

review_list:

this goes on for the month of december, and is a not to miss event. there are millions of lights, and kids preforming. don't miss the train ride and the amusement park, with a merry go round in it's own building. rode the new rolly coaster, and if you like the old fashion kind that don't beat you up, you...

review_list: Wonderful antique type library, the ladies that work there are very nice and know so much history about that area. The library is in algiers point, just take the free ferry and you can walk there on foot. I felt as if I was back in the 50's, it was the highlight of my trip.

review_list: Take the streetcar and see lots of beautiful homes, this is one of the best.

Day. No one answered bell. No signage indicating closure. No one looked to be inside. Very disappointing! I would say to call and check and have a plan B. WWII and children's museums close by.

I did not know that the French Quarter was primarily Italians from Sicily, who also brought Jazz from Chicago at the turn of the century. title: Woldenberg Art Center and Newcomb Art Gallery, New Orleans
address: Tulane University Campus, Willow St. entrance, New Orleans, LA 70118
review_list:
I took a 50-60 minute streetcar ride to Tulane, walked around campus for about 30-40 minutes looking for the right place (abysmal signage) and finally found the Gallery. The Degas exhibit was wonderful and offered a view of the painter not commonly seen. When I asked where the pottery was, I was told that "...they don't have any...". My question...


More  



The gallery is hidden deep in the Tulane campus but it's a beautiful campus to walk through. It is excellently curated. The displays are at eye level, which makes viewing very pleasant. The beautiful pottery, jewelry, prints, and book bindings were done by young women in the 1920s. There are also two beautiful Tiffany stained glass triptychs in the hallway...

If the Newcomb women's college exhibition is up (anywhere), definitely go see it for its stunning craftsman style work, not only pottery but textiles and printing. A love walk through the Tulane campus after a streetcar ride from downtown.

title: Holt Cemetery, New Orleans
review_list:
This cemetery is not included in many of the tourist attractions to visit while in NO. It is vastly different than Metairie and all of the St. Louis cemeteries but it is certainly worth taking 10 minutes to check it out. It is right down the street from Metairie cemetery. It is originally for the indigent population of NO. The...

title: Keil's Antiques, New Orleans
review_list: This is a fabulous place to look for beautiful, unique pieces. Staff are friendly and helpful, everything is classy and immaculate, and the place is not so jam-packed that you feel stuffy and claustrophobic. I definitely recommend stopping in. You never k ow what you'll find!

title: Port Pontchartrain Lighthouse, New Orleans
address: University of New Orleans Research and Technology Park, New Orleans, LA
review_list: We got a chance to visit this historical light house while on the Gray Line tour. So glad that we did, as we learned a more about the area, and the light house. Very interesting facts and guides by an exceptional volunteer group.

review_list: it is a most amazing place to visit...beautiful!...being there as a child the place was overwhelming but, the renovations are very unique.

review_list: They had a nice selection of antique items. I stopped in there to have a look just to see what they had, and a lot of it was really nice and interesting. If you're in the market for some antiques then this would be a good start.

review_list: This sounded like fun to us however it was disappointing. Other than learning who had visited which famous site there was little to learn that could not have been learned from other sources at no cost.

This is amazing collection to really know, value and learn from the past....A lot to get to know about black american history....their Shadows, their struggles and their strength a true reckoning experience. Respect to the place and mankind!!!
Must visit for legacy and history if you are in New orleans

The Treme tour by Milton Carr is a wonderful experience. He is so knowledgeable and so well known in the community. It felt like a friend was taking us around his old neighborhood. Well work the two hour walk. And the Treme Cafe at the end is a treasure!

title: NOLA Flyboarding, New Orleans
review_list:
Anyone can do this!!
I hadn't planned to try it when I went to Nola fly boarding with my friends for a birthday party. I thought I would just watch. Tony made it look so easy and fun I couldn't stay out of the water! He coaches each person through their experience, tailoring instructions for each individual's needs. He makes...


More  



Absolutely amazing time. Tony and his staff know how to make you feel comfortable and valued. I got this as a gift for my fiance and he loved it. We can not wait to go again!

Fly boarding is made fun by these awesome individuals. Tony leads a team that not only knows how to compete at a high level but makes it seem easy for you as a beginner. Expert teaching and coaching throughout the entire time. If you want an amazing experience try this out. The lake water is nice and location offers a...


More  



It is so effortless once you realize all you have to do is simply stand up! FLYBOARDING is defiantly the most amazing experience I've ever had. It will be hard to top this one. Especially for paying less than a hundred dollars!

Flybording with Tony was one of the best experiences and I think everyone should experience it. He was a very nice and great instructor. Everyone has to go and visit Tony and try out the flyboard.

Had an amazing time Flyboarding with Tony & his team. Jeremy was an amazing instructor and taught everyone how to fly. It's an experience you have to have when you visit New Orleans.

So much fun! I think I just found myself a new hobby! Tony is awesome, great instruction and very friendly. Me and my kiddos were up and flying in no time. Price was great and definitely worth every penny! Will absolutely do again!

This review is actually a year in the making. My friend and I went flyboarding last summer. So much fun! If you are looking for something new, this is it! Spending time out on the lake beautiful day doing a crazy water sport is so NOLA. Finish off with cocktails/fresh seafood on the patio at Brisbi's. Can't be beat.

My boyfriend did a lesson during our vacation to NOLA. The instructor was very friendly and supportive, and it was the highlight of my boyfriend's trip.

I took my little sister down to NO as a reward for doing well in school. This was the one thing she really wanted to do, so of course, we did it. this is such a fun outdoor activity in New Orleans! It was my first time in New Orleans and first time on a paddleboard!
